As of 1 June, all group institutes for children aged 18 and under are allowed, on the   basis of the health protocol.  As of 1 June, other social and extracurricular activities for children aged 18 and   under are allowed as well, with the possession of a negative test with effect of 72   hours from all individuals aged 12 and over. For social and extracurricular activities   for children under the age of 18 in open-air spaces, the requirement of weekly testing   for all individuals aged 12 and over remains.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210607142618/https://www.pio.gov.cy/coronavirus/pdf/27052021_faqsMETRA_EN.pdf

No policy change. Schools are open, students must present negative test results weekly.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210705145746/https://cy.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210705151638/https://www.pio.gov.cy/coronavirus/uploads/06052021_answersEN.pdf

Until 9 June, private businesses and the departments/services of the public and   wider public sector, with the exception of the essential services, work with a physical   presence of the staff that does not exceed 50% of the employees.   As of 10 June, the limitation of the physical presence of the employees is lifted  https://web.archive.org/web/20210607142618/https://www.pio.gov.cy/coronavirus/pdf/27052021_faqsMETRA_EN.pdf

No limits on number of employees allowed in the workplace. Restaurants, bars, cafes, service establishments, and other nonessential businesses are allowed to open subject to hygiene and social distancing requirements.     Businesses in Northern Cyprus are subject to stricter restrictions, including limits on operating hours.     Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210624165126/https://www.pio.gov.cy/coronavirus/pdf/27052021_faqsMETRA_EN.pdf    https://web.archive.org/web/20210705175036/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/488786/cyprus-authorities-ease-domestic-covid-19-related-restrictions-as-of-june-10-update-39    https://web.archive.org/web/20210705154802/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/491756/northern-cyprus-authorities-maintaining-covid-19-related-restrictions-as-of-june-17-update-31

As of 1 June, the operation of indoor and open-air cultural spaces (theatres,   amphitheatres and other spaces of performance arts) is allowed at 50% capacity and   in compliance with the health protocols  https://web.archive.org/web/20210607142618/https://www.pio.gov.cy/coronavirus/pdf/27052021_faqsMETRA_EN.pdf

Mass events, gatherings, demonstrations, parades, concerts, festivals, in public or private places, are prohibited, with the exception of events/gatherings/sports events for which guidelines have been issued by the Ministry of Health.     Weddings, christenings, and funerals are allowed to continue. The operation of theatres, amphitheatres, cinemas and performance halls is permitted at a maximum of 50% capacity. Conferences and trade fairs are similarly allowed to continue with restrictions on capacity.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210705180730/https://www.pio.gov.cy/coronavirus/uploads/30062021_PIO%20Decree%20No%2026%20EN.docx.pdf

As of July 1, sporting events are allowed to increase the number of attendees to 50% of stadium capacity. People attending must have either had both vaccine doses, have tested negative for Covid-19, or recovered from Covid-19 within the last six months.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210705152244/https://www.pio.gov.cy/coronavirus/uploads/16062021_neweasingofmeasuresEN.pdf

Under what conditions is it allowed to hold lunches / dinners for social   events, in restaurants, event halls and hotels / tourist accommodation?  As of 1 June, and until 9 June, holding lunches/dinners for weddings and baptisms   is allowed in catering establishments or hotel facilities or event halls, by complying   with the health protocol for social events, as follows:  ? 150 persons in an indoor space for lunch or dinner, or  ? 280 persons in an outdoor space for lunch or dinner  ? Cocktail parties are allowed with a maximum number of 250 persons at any   given time only in an outdoor space.  As of 10 June, and until 30 June, holding lunches/dinners for weddings and   baptisms is allowed in catering establishments or hotel facilities or event halls, by   complying with the health protocol, as follows:  ? 200 persons in an indoor space for lunch or dinner, or  ? 350 persons in an outdoor space for lunch or dinner  ? Cocktail parties are allowed with a maximum number of 250 persons at any   given time only in an outdoor space.  A prerequisite for the attendees is the presentation of evidence of a SAFEPASS  https://web.archive.org/web/20210607142618/https://www.pio.gov.cy/coronavirus/pdf/27052021_faqsMETRA_EN.pdf

Gatherings in private residences are limited to 20 people. Some public events, including religious services or performances, may go ahead with more people but are subject to social distancing requirements and restrictions on capacity.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210705180730/https://www.pio.gov.cy/coronavirus/uploads/30062021_PIO%20Decree%20No%2026%20EN.docx.pdf
No restrictions on public transport.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210705181325/https://cyprus-mail.com/2021/06/11/coronavirus-relaxations-in-public-transport-new-guidelines/

As of 29 May until 9 June, movement is prohibited from 1 o’clock at night until 5   o’clock in the morning.  As of 10 June, the curfew is lifted.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210607142618/https://www.pio.gov.cy/coronavirus/pdf/27052021_faqsMETRA_EN.pdf

Although the nationwide curfew was lifted June 10, a curfew remains in place from 12AM to 5AM in the north of Cyprus.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210705154530/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/cyprus/coronavirus    https://web.archive.org/web/20210705154700/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/488786/cyprus-authorities-ease-domestic-covid-19-related-restrictions-as-of-june-10-update-39    https://web.archive.org/web/20210705154802/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/491756/northern-cyprus-authorities-maintaining-covid-19-related-restrictions-as-of-june-17-update-31
No restrictions.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210705181539/https://www.pio.gov.cy/coronavirus/eng

Visitors from ‘Amber’ category countries are required to undergo a PCR test within 72 hours prior to departure and provide proof of a negative result.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210621152617/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/cyprus

Cyprus is following a color coded scheme to regulate travel. Travelers from green countries are required to complete a Cyprus Flight Pass 48 hours prior to departure. Travelers from orange countries must complete the flight pass and provide evidence of a negative PCR test taken 72 hours prior to departure. Travelers from red countries are required to complete the flight pass, provide evidence of a negative PCR test take 72 hours prior to departure, and also take a PCR test upon arrival in Cyprus. Travelers from grey countries must complete mandatory self-isolation upon arrival.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210705150727/https://www.visitcyprus.com/files/COVID-19_Destination_Protocol_Cyprus_-1st_July_21_FINAL.pdf
No policy change.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210705182756/https://fonts.googleapis.com/css?family=Roboto:300,400,700&subset=latin,greek
No policy change.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210705182756/https://fonts.googleapis.com/css?family=Roboto:300,400,700&subset=latin,greek
Information available on government website.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210705181539/https://www.pio.gov.cy/coronavirus/eng

Aiming at the continuous surveillance of the community and the workplaces, the free   programmes of rapid antigen testing of the general population and employees are in   progress.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210621155147/https://www.pio.gov.cy/coronavirus/uploads/20062021_testingEN.pdf

No policy change. COVID-19 PCR tests are available at designated laboratories at a cost of 50 euro. Those contacted by the Ministry of Health due to contact tracing are entitled to one free test. Physicians can also refer patients for tests at local General Hospitals. Rapid antigen tests are available for free at select sites announced by ROC daily.       Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210703141500/https://cy.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

No policy change. Comprehensive contact tracing in place. During the tracing process the confirmed case is asked to declare the contacts he/she  had two days before the onset of symptoms or two days before the test. Close contacts are subjected to a PCR test, after the arrangement of an appointment by the Public Health Medical Centres, and receive instructions via a text message for self-isolation. Close contacts are placed in mandatory self-isolation for 14 days from their last contact with the case, regardless of the test result.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210524164308/https://www.covid19healthsystem.org/countries/cyprus/livinghit.aspx?Section=3.2+Managing+cases&Type=Section

The use of a face mask is compulsory in all indoor and outdoor public spaces in the Republic of Cyprus. Failure to comply with restrictions may result in a €300 fine.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210524194946/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/cyprus/coronavirus

Johnson&Johnson, AstraZeneca, Moderna and Pfizer/BioNTech   Appointments available for all people over the age of 18  https://web.archive.org/web/20210621155437/https://www.pio.gov.cy/coronavirus/uploads/14062021_vaccinesEN.pdf

Vaccine appointments available for adults 18 and older. Vaccines: Pfizer, Moderna, Johnson & Johnson    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210621155437/https://www.pio.gov.cy/coronavirus/uploads/14062021_vaccinesEN.pdf

Nursing home visits are allowed, but visitors should hold either a negative Covid-19 antigen rapid test performed within 72 hours, a certificate of  vaccination against Covid-19 for at least one dose (provided that three weeks have elapsed after the date of vaccination), or a proof of release for those infected with Covid-19 (provided that a period of six months has not elapsed since the date of the initial positive diagnosis).    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210705180730/https://www.pio.gov.cy/coronavirus/uploads/30062021_PIO%20Decree%20No%2026%20EN.docx.pdf

From the 24th of May, in-person learning is open to higher education students studying theoretical subjects (previously only open to practical subjects) and for all remaining secondary school students. Weekly rotation of classes will end. Students are still required to wear masks during lessons and between lessons.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210612125534/https://www.vlada.cz/en/media-centrum/aktualne/measures-adopted-by-the-czech-government-against-coronavirus-180545/

From the 8th of June, students and teachers no longer have to wear masks while seated during lessons or lectures.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210612125534/https://www.vlada.cz/en/media-centrum/aktualne/measures-adopted-by-the-czech-government-against-coronavirus-180545/

Neither students nor teachers are required to wear face masks during classes in all Czech regions (except for Zlín, South Bohemia and Liberec regions). However, masks remain mandatory during breaks and in common premises.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210628095525/https://www.osu.eu/24712/the-latest-covid-19-related-news/

As of June 15, stricter rules for wearing respiratory protection and face masks in schools in the South Bohemia, Liberec and Zlín regions will be abolished. The requirement for pupils to wear face masks was abolished in all other Czech regions on June 8. Face masks are still required in common premises and during breaks.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210628095525/https://www.osu.eu/24712/the-latest-covid-19-related-news/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210628102104/https://www.vlada.cz/en/media-centrum/aktualne/non-state-cultural-heritage-sites-will-also-receive-financial-support-during-the-epidemic--pupils-in-other-regions-will-put-away-their-masks-and-respi-189246/

Working from home is not mandatory, although the government recommends doing so when possible and regularly testing employees in the work place. Nonessential businesses (including restaurants, bars, and cafes) are allowed to open with restrictions on capacity, social distancing measures and mask requirements in place. Indoor cultural events will be allowed to have up to 1000 spectators (with only half of the auditorium being occupied). As of June 14, the number of spectators at outdoor cultural events will not be limited anymore but the area for spectators without seats must have at least four square meters per spectator.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210628095525/https://www.osu.eu/24712/the-latest-covid-19-related-news/

No policy change. Public events allowed with up to 500 people indoors and 200 people indoors. Persons in attendance must satisfy one of the following criteria: 1) have a negative PCR or antigen test not exceeding 7 days old, 2) have proof of recovery from Covid-19 within 180 days of the event, 3) have proof of receiving the first vaccine dose within 22 days of the event. Citizens of Czechia and foreign nationals with residence permit issued by Czechia, citizens of EU+, and foreign nationals with long-term or permanent residence permit issued by EU+ are allowed to enter the country for any reason. Foreigners (except for travelers from green countries, member states of EU) can come to the Czech Republic only on the grounds of essential reasons, not for tourism or visiting friends.     All other travelers must follow the ""traffic light"" system. People traveling from low risk countries are allowed to enter the country without restrictions. People traveling from medium risk countries are allowed to enter but must provide evidence of a negative PCR/antigen test and complete a Passenger Locator Form. People traveling from high risk and very high risk countries must complete a passenger locator form, provide evidence of a negative test prior to travel, take a PCR test after arrival and self isolate. Travel from extreme risk countries is only allowed for citizens and residents of Czechia or accredited members of diplomatic missions.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210705134322/https://www.mvcr.cz/mvcren/docDetail.aspx?docid=22239932&docType=ART

From the 1st of June, all those participating in public health insurance will have access to POC antigen tests no more than once every 7 days, confirmed by RT-PCR if positive with no symptoms. Persons with public health insurance are entitled to 2 PCR tests per month.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210613095108/https://covid.gov.cz/en/measures/antigenni-testovani-na-koronavirus/voluntary-free-poc-antigen-testing-population  https://web.archive.org/web/20210613095108/https://covid.gov.cz/en/measures/antigenni-testovani-na-koronavirus/voluntary-free-poc-antigen-testing-population

The request for the RT-PCR test (free of charge) can be issued by a doctor or an employee of the regional hygiene station if you have been in contact with an infected person or are exhibiting symptoms. Tests are also available for purchase without a doctor's prescription. From June 8th, pupils and teachers no longer have to wear a mask while seated during lectures or lessons. The same exception applies to employees at their workplace if they are exclusively in the presence of a co-worker.   This relaxation does not apply for the regions South Bohemian, Liberec and Zlín.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210612125534/https://www.vlada.cz/en/media-centrum/aktualne/measures-adopted-by-the-czech-government-against-coronavirus-180545/
No policy change.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210628095610/https://www.vlada.cz/en/media-centrum/aktualne/measures-adopted-by-the-czech-government-against-coronavirus-180545/

As of June 15, stricter rules for wearing respiratory protection and face masks in schools and workplaces in the South Bohemia, Liberec and Zlín regions will be abolished. The requirement for pupils to wear face masks was abolished in all other Czech regions on June 8. Face masks are still required in common premises.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210628095525/https://www.osu.eu/24712/the-latest-covid-19-related-news/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210628102104/https://www.vlada.cz/en/media-centrum/aktualne/non-state-cultural-heritage-sites-will-also-receive-financial-support-during-the-epidemic--pupils-in-other-regions-will-put-away-their-masks-and-respi-189246/

Face masks are mandatory in shops and shopping centers, services, on all forms of public transport, at public transport stops, on platforms and in waiting rooms, at airports, in health and social service facilities, inside official buildings, at post offices, in pharmacies, cars (members of more than one household), and in a workplace (unless alone in a room). Face masks are obligatory outdoors only if two and more people meet with shorter than a two-meter distance, unless they are from the same household.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210705135130/https://www.visitczechrepublic.com/en-US/Covid-19

People over 16 can register for a vaccination. This includes people who do not have public health insurance in the Czech Republic or the European Union but who have resided in the Czech Republic for a long time. Vaccination is voluntary and covered by public health insurance. All persons who are registered for public health insurance in the Czech Republic can be vaccinated free of charge. Vaccines: Pfizer, Moderna, AstraZeneca, Janssen    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210705141726/https://koronavirus.mzcr.cz/ockovani-proti-covid-19/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210705142250/https://covid19.trackvaccines.org/country/czechia/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210705142339/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/information-about-vaccine/information-about-available-vaccines

From the 8th of June, the conditions to visit health and social care facilities are modified. This includes care homes for the elderly.   The validity of PCR tests is extended to 7 days, and that of antigen tests to 72 hours. Tests performed by employers or schools will be recognised too.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210612125534/https://www.vlada.cz/en/media-centrum/aktualne/measures-adopted-by-the-czech-government-against-coronavirus-180545/

Visits to nursing homes are possible if visitors complete one of the following: 1) undergo a PCR test on site, 2) provide evidence of a negative PCR or antigen test that is no more than 72 hours old, 3) provide Covid-19 vaccination certificate (vaccine must have been administered 22 days prior to visit), or 4) prove that you had and recovered from Covid-19 no more than 180 days before the date of the visit.     Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210705143247/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/hospitals-and-sanitary-facilities/visits-social-facilities

Curfews put in place if 7-day incidence > 100: Between 22:00 (10pm) and 5:00 (5am) people will only be permitted to leave their homes if they have a good reason, such as going to or from work, seeking medical assistance or taking a dog for a walk. Until midnight it will be permissible to go for a walk or a jog alone.    Note that vaccinated and recovered individuals are exempt from this (see 9 May note). Coded to reflect the strictest requirement for non-exempt people (2).     http://web.archive.org/web/20210606114744/https://www.bundesregierung.de/breg-en/news/nationwide-emergency-brake-1889136  http://web.archive.org/web/20210606114721/https://oscovida.github.io/germany-incidence-rate.html

Countries and regions around the world are classified into four categories: green, yellow, orange and red. The colour codes determine the rules that must be observed to enter Denmark.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210629025652/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/rules-and-regulations/entry-into-denmark/categorization-of-countries  http://web.archive.org/web/20210629025908/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/rules-and-regulations/entry-into-denmark

Foreigners who are habitually resident in red countries and do not have one of the following special worthy purposes of entry will not be allowed to enter Denmark, not even to be in transit.   Red countries include - Bangladesh, Botswana, Brazil, Eswatini, India, Lesotho, Malawi, Mozambique, Nepal, South Africa, Zambia and Zimbabwe. Test is generally available. It is recommended that you take a PCR test if you have symptoms or if you are the close contact of someone infected with novel coronavirus. In other situations, it might be a good idea to take a rapid antigen test. It is recommended that you get tested even after you have been fully vaccinated.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210519204928/https://www.sst.dk/en/English/Corona-eng/Symptoms_tested-positive-or-a-close-contact/On-being-tested    In Copenhegan, The authorities recommend that you get tested often. If you are going to work or school, then the recommendation is that you get tested once a week.  https://archive.vn/SpjSG     The City of Copenhagen offers a voluntary and free quick test for students who have turned 12 years old.   https://archive.vn/bKUKM    ***Both PCR and LFT (quick) testing are widely available, and all positive quick tests are followed up with a PCR test.

Both PCR and rapid antigen tests are widely available, and all positive rapid tests are followed up with a PCR test.   http://web.archive.org/web/20210629030941/https://www.sst.dk/en/English/Corona-eng/Symptoms_tested-positive-or-a-close-contact/On-being-tested

You will typically be notified that you are a close contact:    - By receiving a call from Coronaopsporing (Corona Tracking) who helps infected persons trace close contacts  - By being contacted by someone you know who has tested positive   - By being contacted in connection with outbreaks of infection in schools, in daycare centres, educational institutions, at workplaces etc.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210629031203/https://www.sst.dk/en/English/Corona-eng/Symptoms_tested-positive-or-a-close-contact/Contact-tracking-and-close-contacts

New rules on the use of face masks in Spain will come into effect on June 26. As of this date, the covering will not have to be worn outdoors if a distance of 1.5 meters can be observed. It will, however, be mandatory to carry a face mask at all times so that it can be put on in situations where social distancing cannot be maintained.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210628033850/https://www.infobae.com/america/mundo/2021/06/26/espana-vive-su-primer-dia-sin-mascarilla-obligatoria-al-aire-libre/

- A: Key workers, nationally covered.  - B: clinically vulnerable people are eligible for vaccination nationally.  - C: People over 80 are fully covered at the national level with two doses. A maximum of 1,000 people are allowed to participate in these events in a restricted outdoor area.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210614100437/https://www.kriis.ee/en/news/covid-19-restrictions-be-relaxed-11-june

(Announced June 22) Beginning June 23, there is no longer a 50% capacity restriction in indoor spaces. This means that engaging in indoor sports activities, youth work, hobby activities and education, refresher training and courses, sports competitions and sports and fitness events, visiting spas, water parks, and swimming pools, organising public meetings and events, including conferences, theatre performances, concerts, and cinema screenings, providing entertainment services, and attending public worship services and other public religious services will be allowed again without the current restrictions on occupancy.    The occupancy requirements applicable to stores and service and catering establishments will also be abolished. However, the requirement for dispersal and disinfection requirements must still be complied with in indoor spaces. Outdoor events can accommodate up to 1,000 participants under the current rules.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210627141210/https://www.kriis.ee/en/news/occupancy-rule-will-be-removed-covid-19-restrictions-tomorrow     https://web.archive.org/web/20210627142718/https://news.err.ee/1608255117/fifty-percent-indoor-occupancy-covid-19-restriction-gone-from-wednesday

From 17 May, visitors may stay in the outdoor areas of museums and exhibitions (including the zoo), subject to a 50% occupancy requirement. The doors must be closed by 10 p.m.    From 17 May, groups of up to 25 people are allowed to attend public events and meetings and entertainment venues outdoors. All events must end by 10 p.m. The total allowed number of outdoor participants is 250 people.    From 24 May, it is allowed to be indoors at museums and exhibitions and participate in seated events in theatres, cinemas, conferences, as well as go to worship services or other public religious services, provided that the 50% occupancy rule is followed. In rooms with fixed seating, the number of allowed participants is 200, excluding performers and people involved in the event who are not in direct contact with the visitors. In museums and exhibition halls, the limit is taken into account together with the occupancy restriction per hall. The event must end by 10 p.m.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210517193455/https://www.kriis.ee/en/news/government-approved-order-concerning-gradual-easing-covid-19-restrictions

Travel to Estonia is possible for: 1) Estonian citizens, residents and their family members, 2) Citizens and residents of the European Union, the Schengen area, the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, Andorra, Monaco, San Marino and Vatican, and asymptomatic individuals with a long-stay visa and their family members, 3) Asymptomatic citizens of foreign states arriving in Estonia from states not named above for work or studies, and family members of a high-level specialist coming to work in Estonia with a visa and family members of a foreign national coming to work in a start-up company or in the field of ICT in Estonia.     A 10-day restriction on the freedom of movement applies on entering Estonia from a country in the European Union, European Economic Area and the Schengen area with an infection rate above 150 persons per 100 000 inhabitants in the past 14 days. When arriving from third countries that are not listed in Annex I, a mandatory 10-day restrictions on movement period also applies to those who are allowed entry to Estonia. Anyone who does not wish to self-isolate for 10 days after their arrival in Estonia can take a PCR test abroad no earlier than 72 hours before their arrival in Estonia. While in Estonia, a second test can be taken no earlier than on the sixth day after the first test. The 10-day restrictions on movement period can be concluded earlier if both tests are negative.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210626031333/https://vm.ee/en/information-countries-and-self-isolation-requirements-passengers

A 10-day restriction on the freedom of movement applies on entering Estonia from a country in the European Union, European Economic Area and the Schengen area with an infection rate above 150 persons per 100 000 inhabitants in the past 14 days.    Travelling to Estonia is possible for the following persons    Travelling to Estonia is possible for the following persons:  Estonian citizens, residents and their family members. Estonian citizens and residents are allowed entry regardless of whether or not they show symptoms of the disease.  Vaccinated third country nationals, for any purpose, if they have a valid Schengen visa.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210626031333/https://vm.ee/en/information-countries-and-self-isolation-requirements-passengers

While areas like Satakunta have face-to-face teaching for all levels areas like Central Ostrobothnia, Lansi-Pohja etc. recommend distance learning for higher education.    In Kanta-Hame, the provincial group decided to recommend switching to distance learning for the last school week from 31 May. The distance learning recommendation applies to secondary education and secondary schools throughout the province, but each municipality looks at the situation on the basis of the regional epidemic situation. In the case of primary school children and early childhood education, it was decided to continue local activities, but regional distance learning solutions are also recommended for primary schools if there are exposures in several classes. It is recommended to keep the early childhood education groups unchanged and small during June.   https://archive.vn/K82Nc   http://web.archive.org/web/20210604215344/https://www.khshp.fi/wp-content/uploads/2021/06/Taulukko_rajoitukset-ja-suositukset-Kanta-Hameessa-30.6.-asti_tilanne-040621.pdf     Central Ostrobothnia - Upper secondary institutes in the area are in distance learning until the end of the semester. There are municipality-specific recommendations when it comes to primary and lower secondary education. https://archive.vn/QDjrV     Southern Finland - In universities and colleges, distance learning is recommended. For secondary education, Municipalities may, at their discretion, operate in a hybrid model or, if the local epidemiological situation allows, in contact teaching. Grades 1-6 can continue contact education. https://archive.vn/IRH1Z     Lansi-Pohja - Distance education is recommended for secondary schools according to the epidemic situation in the municipality. It is recommended that a maximum of ten people take part in contact teaching situations at a time from 24 May 2021. Contact teaching must follow corona safety instructions and ensure adequate safety distances and the use of a mask. https://archive.vn/dpgSB     Kymenlaakso - Remote learning should be continued at higher education institutions. https://archive.vn/OyIf4     Satakunta – School are open. https://archive.vn/KQ2yn

In South Finland, Universities and colleges can transition to contact education while Kante-hame and Kymenlaakso still recommend distance learning for higher education.  Kymenlaakso - https://archive.vn/QphGk  Southern Finland - https://archive.vn/AioaQ

Schools are open in most regions in Finland, however, in Kymenlaakso, Remote learning is continued at higher education institutions.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210629051545/https://korona.kymsote.fi/en/kymenlaakso-recommendations/

The coronavirus situation in Kymenlaakso is in the baseline phase throughout the region, Contact teaching can be arranged in all educational stages. In higher education, it is recommended that teaching is organized in such a way that close contacts can be effectively avoided. These instructions apply to indoor teaching for groups of more than 10 people.   https://archive.vn/2021.07.02-205139/https://korona.kymsote.fi/en/kymenlaakso-recommendations/    Unable to find any other region where there distant learning only at some or all level of education, so code changed to 1G.

On 3 June, the Government decided to extend the restrictions on entry into the country until 27 June 2021.  Restrictions have been lifted earlier for traffic arriving in Finland from the Vatican, and for traffic between Finland and Australia, South Korea, Israel, Singapore, Rwanda and New Zealand for residents of these countries. Entry from these low-risk countries is not restricted due to the low incidence of COVID-19. For other countries, the restrictions on entry will be extended until 27 June 2021.  https://archive.vn/IECUM

Authorities have extended the nation's COVID-19-related international entry restrictions until at least June 27 and amended the list of countries from which travelers may enter Finland. Nationals and residents of Australia, New Zealand, Singapore, South Korea, Israel, Rwanda, Malta, and Iceland arriving directly from those countries may enter Finland without restrictions. Travels from other countries are prohibited.    In addition, from June 7, travelers from EEA and Schengen countries may enter Finland by air for work purposes, while students may enter only for training purposes if included as part of their studies.  https://archive.vn/0p8Al  https://archive.vn/CrgSf

From June 21, Authorities eased the nation's COVID-19-related international entry restrictions. All travelers from the EU and Schengen countries who can provide evidence of being fully vaccinated as well as those who have recovered from the disease no longer than six months prior to entry will be allowed to enter without restrictions. In addition, all those traveling from the EU and Schengen countries for business purposes will be allowed to enter. Officials are also lifting entry restrictions for all travelers arriving from San Marino, Monaco, Romania, Poland, and Hungary. Nationals and residents of Australia, New Zealand, Singapore, South Korea, Israel, Rwanda, Malta, and Iceland may also enter Finland without restrictions. The entry measures are in effect through July 11. Other countries are still prohibited with exceptions.  https://archive.vn/2021.06.29-053421/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/492551/finland-authorities-to-ease-certain-covid-19-international-entry-restrictions-from-june-21-update-21#selection-1745.0-1745.789

When a person is diagnosed with a coronavirus infection, the municipality of residence carries out contract tracing, on the basis of which nearby contacts are quarantined. If a person is not considered a close contact, they can continue their life as normal. Contact tracing can take some time, especially if there are many exposed persons. If you do not know what to do, contact health care to check the situation. https://archive.vn/vuqw5

General guidelines of Elderly care - https://archive.vn/FU2D1     Espoo - You must take particular care when visiting loved ones at our nursing homes and housing units. You can only visit our units if you are healthy and have no symptoms. You should agree on your visits in advance with our staff. All service centres for senior citizens are closed due to the coronavirus situation. Group exercise and other activities have been cancelled.  https://archive.vn/QrEfX     Visits are recommended to be avoided in Kanta Hame. http://web.archive.org/web/20210604215344/https://www.khshp.fi/wp-content/uploads/2021/06/Taulukko_rajoitukset-ja-suositukset-Kanta-Hameessa-30.6.-asti_tilanne-040621.pdf     Southern Finland - With vaccination coverage of more than 90 percent in 24-hour care units, visiting practices in these can be facilitated. https://archive.vn/IRH1Z     Helsinki - The activities of service centres for seniors will be opened up gradually and on a limited basis as of 1 June. Supported small group activities will be opened up first for customers who need the most support. Those invited to the groups will be contacted separately. Services open to all guests, such as a gym and restaurants, will remain closed. Visiting instructions for senior centres remain unchanged.   In senior centres and service houses, indoor visits can last up to an hour and there can be two visitors at a time. Outdoor visits may last up to one hour, and five visitors may be present at a time.  https://archive.vn/y9goi and https://archive.vn/gEjM4     Lansi-Pohja - Visits must be agreed with the business unit. Visitors must be asymptomatic and may be 1-2 at a time. A face mask is used during the visit. Hand hygiene and safety intervals should also be taken care of. https://archive.vn/dpgSB

Satakunta - It is recommended that there be a maximum of two guests at a time. Visits must be carried out in accordance with THL's instructions and protective equipment must be worn throughout the visit. https://archive.vn/P1hWv     Soite - The day activities for the elderly that Care and nursing organize is on pause until the 20th of June. The health centre for the elderly, Daalia: restricted functions from the 7th June to the 11th June 2021. Closed from the 14th June to the 24th June 2021. eSenior activity is paused. Day activities for the elderly are paused until the 20th of June. We will keep in touch with families in other manners.   https://archive.vn/Tjwfj     East Savo - Visits to service housing units are permitted in accordance with the visit guidelines. The visit can only come healthy and up to two people at a time. Prior to visits, it is advisable to contact the unit staff as well as follow the hygiene instructions and wear a mask. https://archive.vn/Lc4J4

New regulations for entry to France were implemented on 9 June, with a system of green/orange/red list countries and different rules for travelers arriving from these lists, and exceptions for certain classes of traveler. Full details at https://web.archive.org/web/20210612160728/https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/conseils-aux-voyageurs/informations-pratiques/article/coronavirus-covid-19    In summary:     ""Green List"" - travellers from a country in the European area or from Australia, South Korea, Israel, Japan, Lebanon, New Zealand, and Singapore, are not subject to ""compelling reasons"" requirements for visiting France. Must provide evidence of a negative PCR test taken within 72 hours before departure, OR proof of complete vaccination with an EMA-approved vaccine.     ""Orange List"" - from all countries not specified in other lists, must:     - all must present negative results of a PCR test taken 72 hours before departure or an antigen test taken 48 hours before departure  - vaccinate travelers not subject to ""compelling reasons"" test for entry  - unvaccinated travelers are subject to ""compelling reasons"", and must self-isolate for 7 days after arrival    ""Red List"" - travelers from a country listed in the order of the Ministry of Health identifying the areas of active circulation of the epidemic or the spread of variants (currently Argentina, Bahrain, Bangladesh, Bolivia, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, India, Nepal, Pakistan, South Africa, Sri Lanka, Suriname, Turkey, Uruguay) must:     - have a ""compelling reason"" to visit France  - negative results of PCR test taken up to 48 hours before departure  - mandatory antigen test on arrival  - mandatory 10 day quarantine on arrival, unless fully vaccinated in which case 7-day self isolation    The ""Compelling Reasons"" allows the following to enter France: French nationals, their spouses and children, nationals of the European area as well as their spouses and children having their principal residence in France or who join, in transit through France, their main residence in a country of the European area or the country of which they are nationals.
No change in policy - https://web.archive.org/web/20210618164740/https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/conseils-aux-voyageurs/informations-pratiques/article/coronavirus-covid-19
No change in policy - https://web.archive.org/web/20210618164740/https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/conseils-aux-voyageurs/informations-pratiques/article/coronavirus-covid-19

No change in policy, but the countries/regions on the green/orange/red lists have been updated on 24 June as follows:    ""Green List"" - travellers from a country in the European area or from Australia, South Korea, Israel, Japan, Lebanon, New Zealand, and Singapore, are not subject to ""compelling reasons"" requirements for visiting France. Albania, Bosnia, Canada, Hong Kong, Kosovo, North Macedonia, Montenegro, Saudi Arabia, Serbia, Taiwan, the USA, and Vanuatu were added to the Green List. Must provide evidence of a negative PCR test taken within 72 hours before departure, OR proof of complete vaccination with an EMA-approved vaccine.     ""Orange List"" - from all countries not specified in other lists, must:     - all must present negative results of a PCR test taken 72 hours before departure or an antigen test taken 48 hours before departure  - vaccinate travelers not subject to ""compelling reasons"" test for entry  - unvaccinated travelers are subject to ""compelling reasons"", and must self-isolate for 7 days after arrival    ""Red List"" - travelers from a country listed in the order of the Ministry of Health identifying the areas of active circulation of the epidemic or the spread of variants (Argentina, Bahrain, Bangladesh, Bolivia, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, India, Nepal, Pakistan, South Africa, Sri Lanka, Suriname, Uruguay, with the addition of Afghanistan, Maldives, Namibia, Paraguay, Russia, Seychelles and the removal of Turkey) must:     - have a ""compelling reason"" to visit France  - negative results of PCR test taken up to 48 hours before departure  - mandatory antigen test on arrival  - mandatory 10 day quarantine on arrival, unless fully vaccinated in which case 7-day self isolation    The ""Compelling Reasons"" allows the following to enter France: French nationals, their spouses and children, nationals of the European area as well as their spouses and children having their principal residence in France or who join, in transit through France, their main residence in a country of the European area or the country of which they are nationals.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210702043227/https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/conseils-aux-voyageurs/informations-pratiques/article/coronavirus-covid-19

Coding remains as 2A, but policy for government support of employers and workers impacted by business reduction was updated in two new decrees issued on 28 May (https://web.archive.org/web/20210601163923/https://www.legifrance.gouv.fr/jorf/id/JORFTEXT000043547031 and https://web.archive.org/web/20210601095303/https://www.legifrance.gouv.fr/jorf/id/JORFTEXT000043547064) which entered into force on 1 June, the details of which are summarised at https://web.archive.org/web/20210601133916/https://www.economie.gouv.fr/covid19-soutien-entreprises/dispositif-de-chomage-partiel    Income support for the self-employed remains unchanged, described at https://web.archive.org/web/20210530143228/https://www.economie.gouv.fr/covid19-soutien-entreprises/reponses-gouvernement-difficultes-independants

Coding remains at 2A, but under the legislation enacted on 28 May there is a gradual tapering down of unemployment support between June and September. In summary (and see https://web.archive.org/web/20210601133916/https://www.economie.gouv.fr/covid19-soutien-entreprises/dispositif-de-chomage-partiel for complete details:     - until June 30, 2021 the rate of partial activity allowance of 70% for the sectors most affected by the health crisis activity (S1 and S1bis sectors) whose turnover suffered a very significant drop (80%) due to health constraints. These companies continue to benefit from 100% partial activity support in June, with no out-of-pocket costs for the employer, throughout the national territory. In this situation, the employee receives 70% of his previous gross remuneration (ie around 84% of the net salary) regardless of the size of the company (and 100% at the minimum wage)    - Companies whose activity has been interrupted by administrative decision due to the health crisis, or which are located in a territorial area subject to specific restrictions (...) when they experience a sharp drop in turnover, or which fall within the most affected sectors and which continue to suffer a very sharp drop in turnover, benefit from a rate of 70% until October 31, 2021    - For common law companies , the decree reduces the allocation rate for the month of June 2021 to 52%. On June 1, the remainder payable by companies in unprotected sectors increases to 25%.    - the rate of subsidy for companies of the most affected sectors by the health crisis is reduced to 60% for the month of July 2021, to 52% for August 2021 and 36% from September 1, 2021. The remaining charges for these companies will be 15% in July, then 25% in August and 40% in September. For the employees of these companies, the rate of the partial activity allowance paid to them drops to 60% of their previous gross compensation (72% net salary) from September 1, 2021.    Income support for the self-employed remains unchanged, described at https://web.archive.org/web/20210530143228/https://www.economie.gouv.fr/covid19-soutien-entreprises/reponses-gouvernement-difficultes-independants

No change in policy. From June 9, the Health Pass comes into effect. Includes 3 types of documentation:  - certificate of negative test - a certificate of positive test of at least 15 days and less than 6 months - certificate of vaccination.   May be paper, or a digital version via the TousAntiCovid application.  The bearer must present their paper pass or QR code when entering an establishment or event that poses a risk of Covid-19 transmission, and will be notified if another visitor subsequently tests positive for Covid-19.   An orange alert is sent if at least one contagious and positive person was in the same place and declared themselves, requiring them to test immediately, to limit contacts and to monitor symptoms. On detection of a cluster, a red alert is sent with instructions to isolate and be tested immediately.  Use of the health pass is required to access certain types of venue, and events over specific sizes depending on location (indoor/outdoor) and type.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210612215746/https://www.economie.gouv.fr/tousanticovid-signal-cahier-rappel-numerique

For travellers from orange and red countries:  Travellers from orange/red countries are only allowed to travel to/through Denmark if they have a worthy purpose.  Travellers from orange/red countries should self-isolate for 10 days after arrival in the Faroe Islands. You must isolate even if the test taken at arrival is negative. The isolation may end after a negative PCR test taken no earlier than on the fourth day after entry.  For travellers from yellow countries:  All travellers (vaccinated and non-vaccinated) from yellow countries, such as certain countries within the EU/Schengen region, are allowed to enter the Faroe Islands without quarantine.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210607192453/https://corona.fo/travel?_l=en

Foreigners arriving from orange and red countries on the Danish government list must have a legitimate reason to enter and are required to isolate upon arrival.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210705173716/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/rules-and-regulations/entry-into-denmark/categorization-of-countries

The UK Furlough Scheme, which supports individuals who cannot work due to their workplace being closed, is set to change from 1 July, though this does not affect people's wages.      The scheme allows employers to keep staff on the payroll but without them coming to work, with the Government paying 80 per cent of their salaries, up to a maximum cap of £2,500.    From 1 July, the Government has reduced its support from 80 per cent of employees’ wages to 70 per cent.    Employers will then have to top up the remaining 10 per cent, so staff still receive 80 per cent of their salaries.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210630172019/https://inews.co.uk/inews-lifestyle/work/furlough-when-end-hmrc-scheme-changes-july-2021-new-rules-how-long-finish-explained-1079553

Contact tracing is performed by the National Public Health Organisation aiming at rapid identification, evaluation, and monitoring of exposed asymptomatic contacts and prompt isolation of those who are found to be clinically ill. A protocol of active contact tracing is being followed from the onset of the pandemic, where for every confirmed case, the 10 closest contacts are being tested, and in case of a second positive result within this pool, further 10 close contacts get tested and so on.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210621222418/https://www.covid19healthsystem.org/countries/greece/livinghit.aspx?Section=1.5+Testing&Type=Chapter

I am in doubt that comprehensive contact tracing was actually well implemented in Greece.  There's no evidence of a clear implementation of such policy (see Taiwan for such examples)  According to my experience in coding other countries, the source quoted by many previous coders, www.covid19healthsystem.org is rather questionable - secondary source, no good reference.

You must use a facemask in all indoor and outdoor public and communal spaces, including work-places and on public transport    https://web.archive.org/web/20210621212959/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/greece/coronavirus
Masks are no longer required in uncrowded outdoor areas. Masks are still required in all indoor areas.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210705081152/https://gr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Pfizer-BioNTech, Moderna, AstraZeneca, Johnson and Johnson / Janssen vaccines have been approved for use in Greece.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210621214504/https://gr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    Currently vaccinating:  Citizens aged 18 or over.  Citizens with underlying diseases, people at high risk from Covid-19 (vulnerable groups)    https://web.archive.org/web/20210621221608/https://emvolio.gov.gr/en

Currently vaccinating:  Citizens aged 18 or over.  Citizens with underlying diseases, people at high risk from Covid-19 (vulnerable groups).  http://web.archive.org/web/20210705191257/https://emvolio.gov.gr/en    Which vaccines are available in Greece? Pfizer-BioNTech, Moderna, AstraZeneca, Johnson and Johnson / Janssen vaccines have been approved for use in Greece  The Greek government determines which vaccine is administered for specific populations.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210705081152/https://gr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
General precautions apply
http://web.archive.org/web/20210705191549/https://eody.gov.gr/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/high-risk_groups.pdf
Schools are fully open with precautions in place    https://web.archive.org/web/20210622110007/https://en.unesco.org/covid19/educationresponse

Restaurants and cafes are open. For indoor dining, you will need to have a ‘corona pass’ (full vaccination, a negative test taken within 72 hours, a positive test taken between 14 days and 12 weeks ago). For outdoor dining, a ‘corona pass’ is not required.    Outdoor attractions, museums, libraries, cinemas, concert venues and gyms are open, but you will need a `corona pass’ for entry. Nightclubs remain closed.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210622110127/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/denmark/coronavirus

Can the authorities ban large gatherings?  Yes. Indoor events, activities etc. with more than 100 people are banned. This ban applies to both public and private events etc.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210622110311/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/rules-and-regulations/national-measures/events-and-gatherings
The outdoor limit on gatherings is 100 people, and the indoor limit is 50 people.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210622110127/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/denmark/coronavirus
Is public transportation operating? Yes    https://web.archive.org/web/20210622110158/https://dk.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/security-and-travel-information/covid-19-information/

Is a curfew in place? No  General stay at home advice apply    https://web.archive.org/web/20210622110158/https://dk.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/security-and-travel-information/covid-19-information/

Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel?  No.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210622110158/https://dk.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/security-and-travel-information/covid-19-information/

Greenland: Tourism travel to Greenland is not permitted at this time due to COVID-19. There are some exceptions to the Greenland border closures, including travel for life and death emergencies.  If your application to travel to Greenland is approved, travelers must present a negative COVID-19 test result taken in a Nordic country (Denmark, Norway, Sweden, Finland, Iceland, or the Faroe Islands) no more than 72 hours prior to travel.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210622110158/https://dk.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/security-and-travel-information/covid-19-information/

Employers are required to:  prohibit the arrival at work of workers who have fever and respiratory problems, especially dry cough and shortness of breath;  reduce physical contact between employees, whenever possible;  introduce sliding working hours, where possible;  organize work in shifts, ie groups, where possible;  reduce the number of physical meetings to a minimum;  regularly ventilate the areas where workers reside and stay.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210617201149/https://www.koronavirus.hr/latest-news/150?__cf_chl_jschl_tk__=48b16d910311b3598b30d21000477d5d7a30f12c-1623957956-0-Ae1Y3GQkTVvUOFvKCGMpcjJrfP8zKRcgXXc4yd9ot8wkuZy1dvc5uPhQTviBjdSAZHgAG7lzRNzWa2yeWTG5dvGtDI3zwleA2DVBG2Pw4ptYSeoylUq1h6x6OyMF0ocDncULwGqxPJXF9nQlqKw0JsJhuctT1l8Nvm_fqLoJzeYqE9AxjHGafrEMNUFfB1EJpYrs-YZe4EuTE_cvrDArXhc5xl6p6Hvie6ITXvNJcsv4eP6sRiwNDSO9OBxseu4NqDKJE13ZKViawDstB7e85ANGD0u-I1-FiThBelrLh6Zh7cN3LSehVhaJXlnEhKS6JuAA0dfWEhFEiW05Va9RCCarN5v_azh-H5gYz-i_d01o7nXJ-Wrq0A_7iI4He6FNOXTU_BRt-_-rgzb7M0DRvPevys_5eI7C5aWMER4sIsmSf9zb4pNnnv_eVATNmSTDuf0oSlfjw2alx4WVPQg0pFE4TxHV3SxTGzKDK3nkmraM  http://web.archive.org/web/20210617201329/https://hr.usembassy.gov/  http://web.archive.org/web/20210617201403/https://www.koronavirus.hr/latest-news/what-to-expect-in-croatia-important-information-for-visitors-950/950  http://web.archive.org/web/20210617201422/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

ban on holding all public events and gatherings attended by more than 100 people in one place *;  public events and gatherings and ceremonies of all kinds can last up to 24.00 hours *;  at funerals, last farewells and funerals, condolences to the bereaved must not be expressed in close contact, and cemetery administrations are obliged to monitor compliance with anti-epidemic measures;  limitation of working hours for bakeries and shops for bread and bakery products up to 24.00 hours;  ban on the sale of alcoholic beverages between 24.00 and 6.00;  restricting the operation of catering facilities and family farms that provide catering services in such a way that food, beverages, beverages and sweets can be served in the open-air service area, in strict compliance with prescribed epidemiological measures and special recommendations and instructions of the Croatian Institute of Public Health. the time can be determined from 6.00 to 24.00 hours  http://web.archive.org/web/20210617201149/https://www.koronavirus.hr/latest-news/150?__cf_chl_jschl_tk__=48b16d910311b3598b30d21000477d5d7a30f12c-1623957956-0-Ae1Y3GQkTVvUOFvKCGMpcjJrfP8zKRcgXXc4yd9ot8wkuZy1dvc5uPhQTviBjdSAZHgAG7lzRNzWa2yeWTG5dvGtDI3zwleA2DVBG2Pw4ptYSeoylUq1h6x6OyMF0ocDncULwGqxPJXF9nQlqKw0JsJhuctT1l8Nvm_fqLoJzeYqE9AxjHGafrEMNUFfB1EJpYrs-YZe4EuTE_cvrDArXhc5xl6p6Hvie6ITXvNJcsv4eP6sRiwNDSO9OBxseu4NqDKJE13ZKViawDstB7e85ANGD0u-I1-FiThBelrLh6Zh7cN3LSehVhaJXlnEhKS6JuAA0dfWEhFEiW05Va9RCCarN5v_azh-H5gYz-i_d01o7nXJ-Wrq0A_7iI4He6FNOXTU_BRt-_-rgzb7M0DRvPevys_5eI7C5aWMER4sIsmSf9zb4pNnnv_eVATNmSTDuf0oSlfjw2alx4WVPQg0pFE4TxHV3SxTGzKDK3nkmraM  http://web.archive.org/web/20210617201329/https://hr.usembassy.gov/  http://web.archive.org/web/20210617201403/https://www.koronavirus.hr/latest-news/what-to-expect-in-croatia-important-information-for-visitors-950/950  http://web.archive.org/web/20210617201422/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

Croatia Airlines maintains flights from Zagreb to and/from most major cities throughout Europe.   With limited exceptions (see the Croatian Government’s Ministry of Interior Webpage), travelers must present a PCR or a rapid antigen test (list of acceptable antigen tests) not older than 72 hours (counting from the time of taking the test to arriving at the border crossing point) OR a certificate of vaccination (any vaccine) whose final dose was more than 14 days prior to entry OR a medical certificate confirming that the traveler has recovered from COVID-19 at least 11 days but no more than 180 days from the first positive test result to date of entry.  For detailed information about these requirements, please visit the Croatian Government’s Ministry of Interior Webpage.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210617201149/https://www.koronavirus.hr/latest-news/150?__cf_chl_jschl_tk__=48b16d910311b3598b30d21000477d5d7a30f12c-1623957956-0-Ae1Y3GQkTVvUOFvKCGMpcjJrfP8zKRcgXXc4yd9ot8wkuZy1dvc5uPhQTviBjdSAZHgAG7lzRNzWa2yeWTG5dvGtDI3zwleA2DVBG2Pw4ptYSeoylUq1h6x6OyMF0ocDncULwGqxPJXF9nQlqKw0JsJhuctT1l8Nvm_fqLoJzeYqE9AxjHGafrEMNUFfB1EJpYrs-YZe4EuTE_cvrDArXhc5xl6p6Hvie6ITXvNJcsv4eP6sRiwNDSO9OBxseu4NqDKJE13ZKViawDstB7e85ANGD0u-I1-FiThBelrLh6Zh7cN3LSehVhaJXlnEhKS6JuAA0dfWEhFEiW05Va9RCCarN5v_azh-H5gYz-i_d01o7nXJ-Wrq0A_7iI4He6FNOXTU_BRt-_-rgzb7M0DRvPevys_5eI7C5aWMER4sIsmSf9zb4pNnnv_eVATNmSTDuf0oSlfjw2alx4WVPQg0pFE4TxHV3SxTGzKDK3nkmraM  http://web.archive.org/web/20210617201329/https://hr.usembassy.gov/  http://web.archive.org/web/20210617201403/https://www.koronavirus.hr/latest-news/what-to-expect-in-croatia-important-information-for-visitors-950/950  http://web.archive.org/web/20210617201422/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

Wearing protective masks is mandatory?in all closed spaces throughout?the country. Masks are also mandatory in open spaces where a physical distance of at least 1.5 meters cannot be maintained.  it is mandatory to wear protective or surgical masks in all enclosed spaces where it is not possible to maintain a distance of 1.5 m. Furthermore, the regulation, which came into force on October 26 2020, stipulates a strict measure regarding physical distancing, with a distance of at least 2 meters indoors and 1.5 meters outdoors. The obligation to use face masks or medical masks outdoors when it is not possible to maintain physical distance was also introduced, as well as the obligation of wearing masks when entering and visiting cemeteries.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210617201149/https://www.koronavirus.hr/latest-news/150?__cf_chl_jschl_tk__=48b16d910311b3598b30d21000477d5d7a30f12c-1623957956-0-Ae1Y3GQkTVvUOFvKCGMpcjJrfP8zKRcgXXc4yd9ot8wkuZy1dvc5uPhQTviBjdSAZHgAG7lzRNzWa2yeWTG5dvGtDI3zwleA2DVBG2Pw4ptYSeoylUq1h6x6OyMF0ocDncULwGqxPJXF9nQlqKw0JsJhuctT1l8Nvm_fqLoJzeYqE9AxjHGafrEMNUFfB1EJpYrs-YZe4EuTE_cvrDArXhc5xl6p6Hvie6ITXvNJcsv4eP6sRiwNDSO9OBxseu4NqDKJE13ZKViawDstB7e85ANGD0u-I1-FiThBelrLh6Zh7cN3LSehVhaJXlnEhKS6JuAA0dfWEhFEiW05Va9RCCarN5v_azh-H5gYz-i_d01o7nXJ-Wrq0A_7iI4He6FNOXTU_BRt-_-rgzb7M0DRvPevys_5eI7C5aWMER4sIsmSf9zb4pNnnv_eVATNmSTDuf0oSlfjw2alx4WVPQg0pFE4TxHV3SxTGzKDK3nkmraM  http://web.archive.org/web/20210617201329/https://hr.usembassy.gov/  http://web.archive.org/web/20210617201403/https://www.koronavirus.hr/latest-news/what-to-expect-in-croatia-important-information-for-visitors-950/950  http://web.archive.org/web/20210617201422/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

Which vaccines are available in Croatia? Pfizer–BioNTech, Moderna, and AstraZeneca.  Croatia is participating in the European Commission’s joint procurement of the COVID-19 disease vaccine, and the vaccine will be available in Croatia at the same time as in other European Union countries.  The current Vaccination Plan has three phases: 1) employees and residents of homes for the elderly (and other institutions that provide accommodation in the social welfare system) and health professionals, 2) all persons over 65 and all persons with chronic diseases, and 3) the rest of the population.   http://web.archive.org/web/20210617201149/https://www.koronavirus.hr/latest-news/150?__cf_chl_jschl_tk__=48b16d910311b3598b30d21000477d5d7a30f12c-1623957956-0-Ae1Y3GQkTVvUOFvKCGMpcjJrfP8zKRcgXXc4yd9ot8wkuZy1dvc5uPhQTviBjdSAZHgAG7lzRNzWa2yeWTG5dvGtDI3zwleA2DVBG2Pw4ptYSeoylUq1h6x6OyMF0ocDncULwGqxPJXF9nQlqKw0JsJhuctT1l8Nvm_fqLoJzeYqE9AxjHGafrEMNUFfB1EJpYrs-YZe4EuTE_cvrDArXhc5xl6p6Hvie6ITXvNJcsv4eP6sRiwNDSO9OBxseu4NqDKJE13ZKViawDstB7e85ANGD0u-I1-FiThBelrLh6Zh7cN3LSehVhaJXlnEhKS6JuAA0dfWEhFEiW05Va9RCCarN5v_azh-H5gYz-i_d01o7nXJ-Wrq0A_7iI4He6FNOXTU_BRt-_-rgzb7M0DRvPevys_5eI7C5aWMER4sIsmSf9zb4pNnnv_eVATNmSTDuf0oSlfjw2alx4WVPQg0pFE4TxHV3SxTGzKDK3nkmraM  http://web.archive.org/web/20210617201329/https://hr.usembassy.gov/  http://web.archive.org/web/20210617201403/https://www.koronavirus.hr/latest-news/what-to-expect-in-croatia-important-information-for-visitors-950/950  http://web.archive.org/web/20210617201422/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

- Hotels in the Republic of Ireland can reopen from 2 June, followed by outdoor service at restaurants and pubs from 7 June.  - Cinemas and gyms will also reopen on 7 June.  - 7 June will see the return of outdoor dining for pubs and restaurants.  - Indoor hospitality will not return until 5 July.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210531091848/https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-57280235  https://web.archive.org/web/20210601110552/https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-57293051

2 June 2021, Ireland will look to ease border restrictions for U.S. and UK travelers starting July 19, Reuters reported, soon after the country plans to begin implementing the European Union's COVID-19 certificate. The plans to ease border restrictions come as the country begins to lift its lockdown measures. Next week, outdoor dining at pubs and restaurants will reopen while hotels will be allowed to welcome guests on Wednesday, the BBC reported. Indoor dining will not be allowed to resume until July 5.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210605020718/https://www.travelandleisure.com/travel-news/ireland-eases-covid-border-restrictions-europe-united-states

13th June 2021, Ireland to consider additional restrictions on travel from Britain    Under consideration are new measures to prevent the spread of the more contagious Delta Covid-19 variant, which was first identified in India and is now the dominant strain in Britain.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210615144847/https://www.reuters.com/world/uk/ireland-consider-additional-restrictions-travel-britain-2021-06-13/

Most arrivals to Ireland must quarantine at home or in their place of residence. If you do not quarantine at home or in your place of residence, you can be fined up to €5,000 or face 6 months in prison, or both. There are very limited exceptions where you do not have to complete home quarantine.    Home quarantine regulations are set out in Statutory Instrument 135 of 2021, as amended, which applies until 19 July 2021.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210629092027/https://www.citizensinformation.ie/en/health/covid19/public_health_measures_for_covid19.html
***Updated to confirm that PCR testing is available for anyone symptomatic: http://web.archive.org/web/20210620162752/https://www2.hse.ie/conditions/coronavirus/testing/how-to-get-tested.html

The following laws apply until 9 November 2021:    You must wear a face covering on public transport unless you have a reasonable excuse for not doing so. This is set out in the Health Act 1947 (Section 31A – Temporary Restrictions) (COVID-19) (Face Coverings on Public Transport) Regulations 2020. Statutory Instrument 569 of 2020 (pdf) requires face coverings in taxis and in bus and rail stations.  You must wear a face covering in shops and other premises that are listed in the regulations, unless you have a reasonable excuse for not doing so. This is set out in Health Act 1947 (Section 31A - Temporary Restrictions) (COVID-19) (Face Coverings in Certain Premises and Businesses) Regulations 2020.      https://drive.google.com/file/d/1iYLIFWNgfcBeHFu5-N2GNPrMvcn-DkO8/view?usp=sharing

The online Covid-19 vaccination portal will open for registration for those aged 40-44 from 2nd June 2021.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210531141515/https://www.independent.ie/irish-news/health/covid-19-vaccine-people-aged-40-44-can-register-for-jabonportal-from-wednesday-40487240.html

As of June 20, broad availability - ""People aged 40 to 69 who have registered for their vaccine are also being vaccinated.""     http://web.archive.org/web/20210620093311/https://www2.hse.ie/screening-and-vaccinations/covid-19-vaccine/rollout/

A,B,C    Groups currently being vaccinated  The at-risk groups vaccinated against COVID-19 are:    people aged 65 and older who live in long-term care facilities (group 1)  frontline healthcare workers (group 2)  people aged 70 and older (group 3)  people aged 16 to 69 who are at very high risk (group 4)  people aged 65 to 69, including those at high risk (group 5 and 6)  people aged 16 to 64 who are at high risk (group 7)  pregnant women between 14 and 36 weeks  People aged 40 to 69 who have registered for their vaccine are also being vaccinated.      The COVID-19 vaccines currently approved for use in Ireland are the:    1) AstraZeneca vaccine (also known as 'Vaxzevria')  2) Moderna vaccine  3) Pfizer/BioNTech vaccine (also known as 'Comirnaty')  4) Janssen vaccine    A number of other vaccines are in the final stages of licensing and approval.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210629092910/https://www2.hse.ie/screening-and-vaccinations/covid-19-vaccine/rollout/

Schools are open again.  In schools and after school activities, at swimming pools, restaurants and at events with seated guests the distance limit is 1 metre.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210607235242/https://www.covid.is/categories/effective-restrictions-on-gatherings

Quote: ""Secondary schools and universities using distance learning and limited running of nursery schools and primary schools.""  Archive Link  http://web.archive.org/web/20210621173005/https://www.covid.is/sub-categories/iceland-s-response
Workplaces open with restrictions. Work from home encouraged.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210607235242/https://www.covid.is/categories/effective-restrictions-on-gatherings

Quote: ""Most businesses and services are permitted to operate subject to hygiene and social distancing requirements""  Archive Link  http://web.archive.org/web/20210621175425/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/490751/iceland-authorities-extend-covid-19-related-travel-restrictions-until-july-1-update-17  _____________________________________________________________________________    Quote: ""Pharmacies, grocery stores and other stores may accept 5 persons for each 10 m2 of space  and a at least 1 metre between persons who are unrelated must be ensured.""  ""Restaurants where alcoholic beverages are allowed may stay open until 24:00 all days of the week with a maximum of 300 guests in each area and must maintain a 1 metre distance rule. All guests must be registered by name, ID No. and telephone number. Alcoholic beverages are to be served to seated guests. All guests must have left the location at 1:00.""  ""Spas and physical training centres are open for their permitted maximum number. However, they may accept a maximum of 300 guests in each area who must be registered beforehand. Spas and physical training centres must ensure  to disinfect equipment and contact surfaces between users.""  Archive Link  http://web.archive.org/web/20210608093308/https://www.covid.is/categories/effective-restrictions-on-gatherings

Up to 300 persons may be present during the ceremonies of religious and life stance ceremonies; stage, cultural and sports events; conferences; lectures; and comparable events provided that the following conditions are met.  Guests may not sit across from each other unless two metres separate them.  Sports competitions are permitted 300 guests also  https://web.archive.org/web/20210607235242/https://www.covid.is/categories/effective-restrictions-on-gatherings

Quote: ""Events with seated guests: Permitted proximity can be less than 1 metre and all guests must wear a face mask. Children born 2005 and later are exempt from wearing a mask. The participation of all guests must be registered to numbered seats and must state their name, ID No. and telephone number. The information is to be preserved for two weeks. Mixing of groups shall be prevented before and after events.""  ""Performing arts, cinema theatres and other cultural events may have up to 150 persons on stage, i.e. during rehearsals and shows. Up to 300 seated guests may be accommodated. Such guests must wear face masks. Seats are to be numbered and labelled with the name of the guest. Selling or offering food and drink during intermissions is permitted. Children born in 2015 and later are not included in this number.    At the ceremonies of religious and life stance associations, up to 300 persons may attend. General restrictions apply to funeral receptions, confirmations and comparable events, i.e. 150 persons in the same area."" Quote: ""Authorities in Iceland have extended the nation's COVID-19-related international entry restrictions until at least July 1. Under most circumstances, travelers from EU and Schengen Area states, as well as those from Australia, Israel, Japan, New Zealand, Rwanda, Singapore, South Korea, and Thailand, can enter Iceland. Most travelers from other locations will remain prohibited from entering with some exceptions, including freight and transport workers, immediate family members of Icelandic residents, diplomats, students, individuals conducting necessary work, and persons traveling for urgent family reasons. Permitted arrivals must complete a preregistration form before departing for Iceland and present a negative result from a COVID-19 polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test taken within 72 hours prior to departure for Iceland. In addition, arrivals must undergo a COVID-19 test at their point of entry and quarantine for five days before taking a second test; travelers without adequate accommodation for self-isolation will be placed in government quarantine facilities.""  Archive Link  http://web.archive.org/web/20210621175425/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/490751/iceland-authorities-extend-covid-19-related-travel-restrictions-until-july-1-update-17  _______________________________________________________________________  Quote: ""Passengers vaccinated against COVID-19 or recovered from it  Yes, until June 30, if you hold an appropriate certificate showing full vaccination or previous infection, you are required to undergo one COVID-19 test upon arrival. The test is free of charge. You must wait for the result of this test (usually received within 5-6 hours but may take up to 24 hours) at your accommodation. You do not need to quarantine for 5-6 days and take a second test.""  ""From July 1, 2021, there is no longer a requirement for arrival testing for passengers fully vaccinated against COVID-19 or recovered from it.    Passengers not vaccinated against COVID-19 and not previously infected  It is mandatory for these passengers to undergo a double COVID-testing procedure along with quarantine for 5-6 days.""  Archive Link   http://web.archive.org/web/20210621184330/https://www.icelandair.com/en-ca/blog/iceland-is-open-faq/

Quote: ""The Government has decided to pay a special supplement over and above basic unemployment benefits next year, so as to support the large group of people whose income-linked unemployment benefits will expire in the next few months. The 2.5% supplement will be paid in addition to the 3.6% increase provided for in the 2021 fiscal budget proposal. With these increases, which total 6.2%, basic unemployment benefits will equal ISK 307,403 per month.    Increased payments for support of job-seekers’ children will be extended through the end of 2021, with a 6% supplement added to basic unemployment benefits for each child instead of the previous 4%. Moreover, a December supplement of just over ISK 86,000 will be paid to confirmed job-seekers.""  ""The Government of Iceland has announced various measures to mitigate the economic and societal effects of the coronavirus outbreak.  Resilience subsidies, For entities suffering revenue losses between 60% and 80%, Support for families with children, Support for disability pensioners and vulnerable groups.""  Archive Link  http://web.archive.org/web/20210621193222/https://www.government.is/government/covid-19/  ______________________________________________________________  Quote: ""Key Policy Responses as of June 3, 2021  Key measures to support households and firms include tax cuts, deferrals, and loss offsets; increased unemployment benefits, child allowances, quarantine grants, hiring grants, subsidies, state contributions to firms’ dismissal costs to prevent bankruptcies of viable firms and protect workers’ rights; incentives for employment of individuals with more than 12-months in the unemployment roster, early pension withdrawals, and state-guaranteed loans to companies.""  Archive Link  http://web.archive.org/web/20210621194408/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

No changes found   Quote: ""Key Policy Responses as of June 3, 2021  Key measures to support households and firms include tax cuts, deferrals, and loss offsets; increased unemployment benefits, child allowances, quarantine grants, hiring grants, subsidies, state contributions to firms’ dismissal costs to prevent bankruptcies of viable firms and protect workers’ rights; incentives for employment of individuals with more than 12-months in the unemployment roster, early pension withdrawals, and state-guaranteed loans to companies. Key measures to restart the economy include public investment, tax incentives for real estate improvement and innovation, temporary tax relief for the tourism sector, a domestic travel gift, and marketing efforts to encourage tourism in Iceland. ""  Archive Link  http://web.archive.org/web/20210621194408/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

Quote: ""Facemasks are no longer required in shops and workplaces; facemasks are now only required for events such as theater performances, church attendance, as well as for close contact services such as hairdressing.""  Archive Link  http://web.archive.org/web/20210621175425/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/490751/iceland-authorities-extend-covid-19-related-travel-restrictions-until-july-1-update-17  _____________________________________________________________  Quote: ""Face masks shall be used where ventilation is poor and where a 2-metre distance is not possible. They shall also be used where it is not possible to ensure a 2-metre distance limit such as in health services, domestic flights and ferries, public transport, taxis and coaches, in practical driving lessons and flight training, hairdressers, beauty salons, massage parlours, tattoo parlours, dog grooming salons, tanning salons and other similar activities. Face masks shall cover the nose and mouth.  Exempted from masks are those individuals who have already been infected with COVID-19 and completed isolation. Furthermore, those who do not have the understanding or maturity to use a face mask correctly or are unable to do so for other reasons, such as health reasons, are exempt from the obligation to wear a mask.""  Archive Link  http://web.archive.org/web/20210608093308/https://www.covid.is/categories/effective-restrictions-on-gatherings

Quote: ""International Travel Restrictions International travel restrictions are still in effect; visa-free travel remains suspended. Authorities have also suspended 72-hour visa-free stays for Chinese and Indian nationals. However, flights with several countries have resumed, including Belarus, Egypt, Germany, South Korea, Kyrgyzstan, the Netherlands, Russia, Turkey, Ukraine, the United Arab Emirates (UAE), and Uzbekistan, though capacity is likely to be limited""  Archive Link  http://web.archive.org/web/20210627193837/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/492586/kazakhstan-authorities-update-list-of-regions-based-on-covid-19-epidemiological-risk-june-17-update-41  _______________________________________________________  Quote: ""Entry and Exit Requirements     Are U.S. citizens permitted to enter?  Yes, subject to strict limitations.  The U.S. Embassy and Consulate in Kazakhstan advises potential travelers to reconsider visits to Kazakhstan at this time due to the risk of COVID-19 in country. We remind you that the Kazakhstani border remains closed to foreigners with limited exceptions, including diplomats, direct-family members of Kazakhstani citizens, residency permit holders, some employees of designated companies in critical industries, and citizens of those countries with which Kazakhstan has resumed direct flights.  Even U.S. citizens qualified for one of these exceptions MUST have a visa in order to enter the country, as the Government of Kazakhstan has extended the suspension of visa-free travel for U.S. citizens to Kazakhstan through December 31, 2021.""  Archive Link  http://web.archive.org/web/20210627192848/https://kz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  _________________________________________________  Quote: ""Entry to Kazakhstan  Most foreign nationals, including those from the UK, are currently prevented from travelling to Kazakhstan."" Border remains closed to foreigners with limited exceptions (including diplomats, direct-family members of Kazakhstani citizens, residency permit holders, some employees of companies in critical industries, citizens of those countries with which Kazakhstan has resumed direct flights). Foreign permanent residence holders and foreign family members of permanent residents and citizens may cross the border once every 30 days and the family members must provide evidence of the family ties (f.e. marriage/ birth certificates).    https://web.archive.org/web/20210705201916/https://kz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Quote: ""Key Policy Responses as of June 3, 2021  In the summer of 2020, the authorities provided additional cash transfers to individuals who lost their jobs due to the quarantine, lowered subsidized interest rates for SME loans (to 6 percent), and extended tax concessions for vulnerable individuals and businesses. Given the ongoing second wave of the pandemic, measures such as “Employment Roadmap“ and support for SMEs (credit support, tax and loan payment deferrals) are expected to continue in 2021. The revised 2021 budget also includes additional COVID-related spending (0.6 percent of GDP) for the vaccines, testing and personal protective equipment, medical services and personnel, and construction of new health facilities. In addition, salary increase for doctors over 2021-23 have been announced with the estimated overall fiscal cost at 0.7 percent of 2021 GDP. The overall fiscal stimulus package in 2021 amounts to about 1.6 percent of GDP.""  Archive Link  http://web.archive.org/web/20210628191417/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
