""Scrambling to save its tourism sector, Portugal said on Wednesday it would allow U.S. visitors into the country but added Nepal to a list of ""red"" nations amid worries about new coronavirus variants.  Portugal is now open to tourists from EU countries and Britain but they must show a negative COVID-19 test result on arrival. Since June 15, rules applied to UK visitors also apply to those coming from the United States, the government said.  Travellers from Japan, Australia, South Korea, China, Israel, New Zealand, Rwanda, Singapore and Thailand will also be able to travel to Portugal as long as their governments adopt equivalent reciprocal measures.  (...) Portugal is lifting travel restrictions on some countries but imposing new rules on others. A ban on non-essential travel applies to all non-EU and non-Schengen zone countries not listed by the government as an exception.  Travellers from Nepal, where daily cases have been dropping but where the new variant of COVID-19 initially discovered in neighbouring India has been detected, must quarantine for 14 days upon arrival.""  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210618235859/https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/portugal-allows-us-tourists-imposes-travel-restrictions-nepal-2021-06-16/

""MAINLAND Portugal    ALLOWED (Essential and non-essential travel)  Countries of the European Union, Schengen Associated countries (Liechtenstein, Norway, Iceland, Switzerland), UK, Australia, New Zealand, China, Israel, Japan, South Korea, Rwanda, Singapore, Thailand, the special administrative regions of Hong Kong and Macau and the United States of America    RT-PCR Test (or similar NAAT test) - 72h before boarding, or  Rapid Antigen Test - 48h before boarding, or  EU Digital COVID Certificate (from 1 July)  Children under 12 do not need to present test.  All passengers need to fill a Passenger Locator Card before departure to Portugal or on board at https://portugalcleanandsafe.pt/en/passenger-locator-card  LIMITED (Only essential travel)  Brazil, India, Nepal, and South Africa    RT-PCR Test (or similar NAAT test) - 72h before boarding, or  Rapid Antigen Test - 48h before boarding, or  Need to comply with quarantine of 14 days after arrival in Portugal;  Children under 12 don’t need to present test.  All passengers need to fill a Passenger Locator Card before departure to Portugal or on board    (...) “Essential travel” is defined as trips allowing the transit, entry into and departure from Portugal for professional purposes, study, family reunions, health and humanitarian reasons and under the reciprocity principle.""    Source: https://archive.vn/IMf3c

"" Arriving to Portugal by Plane    MAINLAND Portugal    ALLOWED (Essential and non-essential travel)    - Countries of the European Union, Schengen Associated countries (Liechtenstein, Norway, Iceland, Switzerland), Albania, Australia, China, South Korea, United States of America, Israel, Japan, Lebanon, New Zealand, Republic of Northern Macedonia, Rwanda, Serbia, Singapore, Thailand, Taiwan  RT-PCR Test (or similar NAAT test) - 72h before boarding, or  Rapid Antigen Test - 48h before boarding, or  EU Digital COVID Certificate (from 1 July)  Children under 12 do not need to present test.  All passengers need to fill a Passenger Locator Card (individually) before departure to Portugal or on board at https://portugalcleanandsafe.pt/en/passenger-locator-card  LIMITED    - Brazil, India, Nepal, and South Africa (Only essential travel)  RT-PCR Test (or similar NAAT test) - 72h before boarding, or  Rapid Antigen Test - 48h before boarding, or  Need to comply with quarantine of 14 days after arrival in Portugal;  Children under 12 don’t need to present test.  All passengers need to fill a Passenger Locator Card (individually) before departure to Portugal or on board at https://portugalcleanandsafe.pt/en/passenger-locator-card  Passengers from the UK (Essential and non-essential travel)     All travellers to mainland Portugal (aged 12 or older) are required to show a negative Covid-19 test:  - RT-PCR taken within 72 hours of departure or  - Lateral flow test taken 48 hours prior to departure  Comply with 14 days of prophylactic isolation on arrival in Portugal, or  Have complete vaccination for 14 days.  Children and young people that are yet to complete 18 years old at the time of their departure flight are exempt from quarantine as long as they travel accompanied by their parents, parent or responsible adult that are fully vaccinated/immunised as per EU directives    * Children under 12 years old are exempt of testing requirements  * Young people from 12 to 18 years old must comply with testing requirements  All passengers must complete the Passenger Locator Card (individually), prior to departure to Portugal or on board, available at: https://portugalcleanandsafe.pt/en/passenger-locator-card  Passengers required to undergo prophylactic isolation must register at https://travel.sef.pt    (...) Arriving to Portugal by Road    No restrictions of entrance, except for citizens coming from Brazil, India, Nepal, and South Africa in the last 14 days, only for essential travel:  Must comply 14-day quarantine period at home or at a place indicated by the health authorities;    (...) Passengers from the UK  Comply with 14 days of prophylactic isolation on arrival in Portugal, or  Have complete vaccination for 14 days.  Children and young people that are yet to complete 18 years old at the time of their departure flight are exempt from quarantine as long as they travel accompanied by their parents, parent or responsible adult that are fully vaccinated/immunised as per EU directives    * Children under 12 years old are exempt of testing requirements  * Young people from 12 to 18 years old must comply with testing requirements    (...) Arriving to Portugal by Train    No restrictions of entrance except for citizens coming from Brazil, India, Nepal, and South Africa in the last 14 days, only for essential travel:  Must comply 14-day quarantine period at home or at a place indicated by the health authorities;  Must register before entering the country at https://travel.sef.pt    Passengers from the UK  Comply with 14 days of prophylactic isolation on arrival in Portugal, or  Have complete vaccination for 14 days.  Children and young people that are yet to complete 18 years old at the time of their departure flight are exempt from quarantine as long as they travel accompanied by their parents, parent or responsible adult that are fully vaccinated/immunised as per EU directives    * Children under 12 years old are exempt of testing requirements  * Young people from 12 to 18 years old must comply with testing requirements    (...) “Essential travel” is defined as trips allowing the transit, entry into and departure from Portugal for professional purposes, study, family reunions, health and humanitarian reasons and under the reciprocity principle.""    Source: https://archive.vn/5N6pC

""policy measures for the first half of 2021 adopted on December 10 and December 22, including towards carrying out the 2021 state budget, comprise: (i) employment support measures via an extension of the support for progressive resumption of economic activity for micro, small and medium-sized enterprises (50% reduction in social contributions, with wages for hours not worked paid at 100%, up to the limit of three monthly minimum wages), and renewed incentives for the normalization of activity (up to 2 national minimum wages per worker) for micro-companies with a drop in turnover above 25 percent; (...) new and expanded credit lines, targeting SMEs (€750 mln), exporters and tourism sector (€1,050 mln, with loans up to €4,000 per worker, of which 20 percent can be converted into a non-refundable subsidy if jobs are maintained) (...)""  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210620140339/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19  Note: Code subject to interpretation - selected 1 because for e.g. 1) subsidy provided those working in the cultural sector ended in May (source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210619010552/https://expresso.pt/coronavirus/2021-05-03-Covid-19.-Aberto-acesso-a-ultimo-apoio-de-43881-euros-para-profissionais-da-Cultura-47d3100e) and 2) workers are entitled to 100% of their remuneration in layoff but only up to 1,995 euros (three times the value of the national minimum wage).

Previous measures remain in place.    July 1 - Considering the current epidemiological situation, the Government extends until September 30 the conditions for payment of the Covid-19 sickness subsidy, which is paid in the amount corresponding to 100% of the net reference remuneration.    Source: https://archive.vn/GxsL8

""The Portuguese government has approved a moratorium on bank loan repayments for households and companies affected by the coronavirus outbreak which has been extended until end-September 2021. The date by which households and companies can avail themselves of the moratoria was extended to end-March 2021.""    Source: https://archive.vn/Aczcv    ""A decree-law was approved that safeguards that the current beneficiaries of the rent payment support scheme can access it until 1 October 2021, verifying the need to maintain a set of measures aimed, in the short term, to safeguard the right to housing.     Modifications to this exceptional and temporary regime were also introduced to ensure that the beneficiaries, between the moment of submission of the request for support and the final decision by the IHRU, are not subject to the effects of default or contractual breach.    The ban on the suspension of the supply of essential services such water, electricity, natural gas and electronic communications services was also extended.""    Source: https://archive.vn/GxsL8
No change in policy.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210625002102/https://www.sns.gov.pt/monitorizacao-do-sns/vacinas-covid-19/
Ongoing public health campaign.    Examples: https://archive.vn/bCv3W  https://archive.vn/ep0yz

""COVID-19 self-tests will become part of the National Testing Strategy for SARS-CoV-2, in accordance with the norm of the General Directorate of Health (DGS), according to which health centers can test asymptomatic patients, if they consent.""  Source: https://archive.vn/HR71E#selection-529.0-529.240

""The Government announced this Wednesday that COVID-19 testing will be mandatory to have access to sports, cultural and family events, including weddings and baptisms.  It will also be necessary to carry out tests in companies with more than 150 workers. (...) The minister explained that these companies, as determined by the health authority, are, similarly to what happens at this time in agriculture and civil construction, to test their staff.  Mariana Vieira da Silva explained that the cost of the tests will be borne by the companies and that this testing requirement ""depends on the guidelines provided by the health authority that will determine the locations in which, given the level of incidence, evolution or growth, this control must done"".   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210611231830/https://www.dn.pt/sociedade/quatro-concelhos-nao-avancam-e-ha-dez-em-alerta-13820087.html

""The Directorate-General of Health updated today, June 17, the Norm referring to the National Testing Strategy for SARS-CoV-2, reinforcing the performance of laboratory tests as a measure to control community transmission.  There is now an obligation to carry out laboratory tests at family events, including weddings and baptisms, as well as any other similar celebrations, with gathering of people outside the household, professionals and participants whenever the number of participants exceeds 10.  In cultural, sporting or corporate events, testing must be carried out whenever the number of participants/spectators exceeds 1,000, in an open environment, or more than 500, in a closed environment.  In a work context, in places with a higher risk of transmission, such as farms and the construction sector, testing is recommended every 14/14 days. The same recommendation must be followed in public services and in workplaces with 150 or more workers (...)""  Source: https://archive.vn/o3AJH

""free testing at pharmacies in Lisbon is no longer limited to two monthly tests per resident in the city, that is now offering an unlimited number of tests, regardless of whether you are a resident of Lisbon or not, informed the Lisbon City Council. Since March 31, when the autarchy's program started, more than 60 000 free tests have been carried out for Lisbon residents.  The number of tests carried out, in pharmacies and mobile stations organized by the local authority and the Red Cross, more than doubled in the last week: from a daily average of 1,000 tests to more than 3,500 tests/day, on 17 and 18 June.  The network of mobile testing points, with 17 points, will also be reinforced as of this week (...) Starting this Monday, teams from the municipal civil protection services will be in the main commercial areas to “raise, door to door, local businesses and restaurants to the need to test their employees”.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210625212728/https://rr.sapo.pt/2021/06/23/pais/covid-19-lisboa-com-mais-um-centro-de-vacinacao-a-partir-de-quarta-feira/noticia/243498/

The Portuguese Red Cross is carrying out PCR tests that provide results in 13 minutes. The new testing method was introduced this Thursday, but since June 1215 tests have already been carried out in various cities across the country.  Source: https://archive.vn/q4Pv1

Starting on Thursday, July 1st, the government will start providing a 100% refund for rapid antigen tests (for professional use). This measure will be in place until July 31st and might be extended. However, there are a few exceptions: it is limited to 4 tests per month/per person (the maximum amount has been fixated at 10€) and those who have completed their vaccinatation in the past 14 days, those who have had COVID-19 in the past 180 days (and have a certificate) are excluded. Only patients of the Sistema Nacional de Saúde (National Health System) are eligible.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210701214059/https://www.dn.pt/sociedade/comparticipacao-de-testes-rapidos-de-antigenio-entra-em-vigor-esta-quinta-feira-13890972.html

The report of the Directorate General for Health and the National Institute Doctor Ricardo Jorge, notes that has been a delay in the epidemiological surveys in Lisbon. According to the report, more the 1000 surveys have not been conducted. The increase in the number cases in the region is leading to delays in identification and isolation of cases.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210625003829/https://www.rtp.pt/noticias/pais/mais-de-1000-inqueritos-epidemiologicos-atrasados-em-lisboa-e-vale-do-tejo_v1328975

According to the President of the Portuguese Association of Family Doctors ""hundreds, if not thousands"" of contacts have not been traced due to the increase in cases in the pas few weeks and the lack of human resources.    Source: https://archive.vn/0ANl9#selection-1397.2-1397.326

Policy remains unchanged.  In addition, the Prime-Minister, António Costa announced in a press conference that it is premature to make any changes to current policy since the transmission rate is still high. He added that evidence is still limited on whether vaccinated individuals are able to spread the virus or not.   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210602160213/https://www.jn.pt/nacional/bares-lojas-restaurantes-e-desporto-o-que-muda-e-o-que-fica-na-mesma-13797405.html

The Portuguese Parliament approved the extension of diploma that makes the use of masks (those aged 10 or above) mandatory outside, in cases when social distancing is not possible, until mid-September. Individuals who have a medical justification or who belong the same household (in cases when other people are not present) are excempt.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210611225847/https://www.dn.pt/sociedade/parlamento-renova-ate-meio-de-setembro-obrigacao-de-usar-mascara-na-rua-13820679.html

June 9, 2021 - The Portuguese Parliament approved the extension of diploma that makes the use of masks (those aged 10 or above) mandatory outside, in cases when social distancing is not possible, until mid-September. Individuals who have a medical justification or who belong the same household (in cases when other people are not present) are excempt.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210611225847/https://www.dn.pt/sociedade/parlamento-renova-ate-meio-de-setembro-obrigacao-de-usar-mascara-na-rua-13820679.html

The coordinator of the COVID-19 vaccination task force, Vice Admiral Gouveia e Melo, announced that people between 20 and 30 years old will likely start being vaccinated in early August. In addition, starting on Sunday, June 6th, people over 40 years old will be called through local appointments and one week later these will be made available online. He also announced that those who had COVID-19 six months ago have started being vaccinated.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210605012434/https://expresso.pt/coronavirus/2021-06-01-Covid-19.-Pessoas-entre-os-20-e-os-30-anos-comecam-a-ser-vacinadas-em-agosto-avanca-Gouveia-e-Melo-a94b6bd7

""The self-scheduling of the vaccine against Covid-19 will be available from the next few hours this Monday for people aged 40 or over (...) Since last Monday, those aged 43 or over can schedule an appointment for the vaccine, which will now be extended.   According to Público , those over 30 should also be able to schedule the vaccine from next Sunday, June 20 (...) people over 30 and 40 years old will be vaccinated at the same time. The goal is to avoid wasting the Janssen vaccine, which, last Tuesday, was recommended by the General Directorate of Health to all men aged 18 years and over.  Until this Monday, in mainland Portugal, more than six million and five hundred thousand doses of vaccines against Covid-19 had been administered — more than four million first doses and more than two million second doses.""  Source: https://observador.pt/2021/06/14/pessoas-com-40-ou-mais-anos-podem-agendar-vacinacao-a-partir-desta-segunda-feira/

Those aged 35 and above are now able to schedule their vaccination appointment online.  By June 20, more than 4.7 million people had already received the first dose of the COVID-19 vaccine, equivalent to 46% of the population and 2.9 million, equivalent to 29% of the Portuguese population were fully vaccinated. In one week, 381,498 additional people were fully vaccinated against covid-19.   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210625004630/https://www.jornaldenegocios.pt/economia/coronavirus/detalhe/autoagendamento-da-vacina-para-maiores-de-35-anos-ja-esta-disponivel  The COVID-19 task force announced today that those aged 18 and above will start being vaccinated on July 4th.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210625005009/https://sicnoticias.pt/especiais/coronavirus/2021-06-23-Covid-19.-Vacinacao-para-maiores-de-18-anos-comeca-a-4-de-julho-12c1990a

According to the Directorate General of Health, those aged 33 and above are now able to schedule their vaccination appointment online.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210701214020/https://www.dn.pt/sociedade/ja-esta-disponivel-auto-agendamento-da-vacina-a-maiores-de-33-anos-13883648.html

""The Government announced today that it will be mandatory to carry out diagnostic tests to covid-19 in order to have access sports, cultural and family events, including weddings and baptisms (...) The minister also said that in areas where significant testing has been carried out, such as education, nursing homes and health, “greater control of the pandemic is possible”.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210626133515/https://www.lusa.pt/article/32323422/covid-19-testes-passam-a-ser-obrigat%C3%B3rios-para-eventos-desportivos-culturais-e-familiares

""The Minister of Health, Marta Temido, said this Tuesday that there is no need to limit visits to nursing homes again, noting that people who are vaccinated and then get infected with COVID-19 develop only ""mild illness"".    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210625002638/https://www.dn.pt/sociedade/ministra-da-saude-afasta-limitacao-de-visitas-a-lares--13862440.html    Visitors to care homes and long-term care facilities must:  ""schedule their visits with a limited time (not to exceed 90 minutes)  respect the limit of one visitor per user  respect physical distance requirements, respiratory etiquette and hand hygiene  use a mask, preferably surgical, during the entire period of stay in the institution  not take personal objects, food or other products  do not move around the institution or use the users' sanitary facilities.  ensure that the visit takes place in its own space, spacious and with airing conditions, and visits should not be carried out in the user's living room or in the bedroom itself, except in cases where the user is bedridden  visitors who test positive for COVID-19 should inform the local health authority if they have visited the institution within 48 hours before the onset of symptoms  communication using video call or telephone should be privileged   if visitors have signs or symptoms suggestive of COVID-19 or have had contact with a suspected or confirmed case of COVID-19 in the last 14 days they should not visitors""    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210626132549/https://www.sns24.gov.pt/tema/doencas-infecciosas/covid-19/desconfinamento/

The vaccination task force announced elderly and employees of homes who have been infected for more than three months will start being vaccinated against covid-19. Previously the minimum period was 6 months. A source from the structure that coordinates the vaccination logistics said that Social Security had identified around 8600 people to be vaccinated in elderly homes, among users and employees of these structures. Due to the increased risk of most of this universe, given their advanced age, the task force and the Directorate-General for Health (DGS) considered it prudent to make an exception to the provisions of standard 002/2021 and proceed with the vaccination of all employees and users who were infected more than 3 months ago (and not 6 months). The DGS standard indicates that people who have recovered from SARS-CoV-2 virus infection for at least six months can be vaccinated, but will receive only one dose of vaccine, bearing in mind that, as they have already had the disease and have immunity.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210626131950/https://www.publico.pt/2021/06/22/sociedade/noticia/task-force-antecipa-vacinacao-lares-1967530

Restaurants and cafés may open between 05:00-24:00 at 70% capacity or full capacity if all guests are vaccinated. Gyms and fitness facilities may open at 70% capacity with seven meters distance between clients or full capacity if all clients are vaccinated.  In certain localities with low incident rates, masks may not be required. Museums, public swimming pools may operate at 70 per cent capacity.     https://archive.vn/qnADk   https://archive.vn/vztLy

Authorities in Romania have eased several domestic COVID-19-related restrictions on June 1 following a significant decrease in infection rates. Among unvaccinated residents, groups of up to eight persons may gather outdoors, overall, Outdoor gatherings are limited to 1,000 persons. Limitations on attendance at indoor gatherings including concerts, weddings and other cultural, leisure, or religious activities, have been lifted provided all the attendees are vaccinated. Gyms, fitness centres, museums, public swimming pools, and restaurants may operate at 70 per cent capacity.   Private events (weddings, baptisms, and birthdays) may accommodate a maximum of 70 guests outdoor, 50 guests indoor, or unlimited guests if those attending are all vaccinated.     https://archive.vn/qnADk   https://archive.vn/vztLy

Currently, there is neither curfew nor stay at home requirements in Romania.     https://archive.vn/9KbQz

There are no restrictions on intercity travel with the exception of areas placed under localized quarantine. There are currently no such restrictions according to the information about the localities placed under lockdown found on the website of the Romanian Ministry of Interior.    https://archive.vn/qnADk   https://archive.vn/9KbQz

International Entry RestrictionsUnder most circumstances, only travellers from European Economic Area (EEA) and EU countries are permitted to enter Romania. Exceptions are in place for family members of EEA citizens and residents, individuals travelling for essential work or study, individuals in transit, and individuals travelling for urgent reasons. Authorities keep and regularly update a list of ""high-risk"" countries. The list of high-risk countries includes Estonia, Czech Republic, Hungary, Poland, Cyprus, Sweden, France, Italy, Austria, Belgium, Turkey, and the Netherlands, among others.    Permitted individuals arriving from countries not included on the list of high-risk areas can enter without restriction. Individuals arriving from high-risk countries must provide a negative result from a COVID-19 test taken within the previous 72 hours and self-isolate for 14 days on arrival; this can be reduced to 10 days by testing negative for COVID-19 on day eight of self-isolation. Cross-border workers, transport workers, and individuals in transit remaining in Romania for less than 24 hours are exempt from the quarantine requirements. Individuals who can present proof they have received a full course of vaccination against COVID-19 no less than 10 days ago or have been confirmed positive for COVID-19 and recovered in the previous 90 days are also exempt from the quarantine requirements.    https://archive.vn/vztLy

No policy change found.     The government included in the 2021 budget some support measures to be extended in 2021. The possibility to reschedule tax payments have been also extended in 2021. It also further raised the cumulative envelope of government guarantees for loans to total around 4 per cent of GDP.      https://archive.vn/9KbQz   https://archive.vn/uLFla   https://archive.vn/j2j9S   https://archive.vn/WujLU

Vaccines used in Romania are the following: Pfizer, Moderna, AstraZeneca, Johnson&Johnson. STAGE I Health and social workers, STAGE II High-risk population, STAGE III the general population.  Priority groups for vaccination against COVID-19 are the following: 1) Health personnel; 2) Staff in residential and medical and social centres; 3) Population at high risk of severe evolution in case of SARS-CoV-2 infection; 4) Staff in other key areas, essential to the smooth running of the company. Currently, Romania is on STAGE III.     https://archive.vn/tK7lq   https://archive.vn/ymYgb#   https://archive.vn/H1SXG
Vaccination policy Stage II includes high-risk population more specifically adults over 65 years of age.      https://archive.vn/H1SXG

Lessons at Moscow schools were not interrupted even during the pandemic. They managed to establish a distance learning system in just one week in March 2020. Lessons were held in such a way till the end of the academic year.     Schoolchildren without their own gadgets were provided with laptops and tablets: over 18 thousand children received them. The main training resource was Moscow Electronic School. This is an online platform with over 53 thousand scripts of lessons for all classes and all subjects, 1.7 thousand study guides, virtual labs, tests and everything you need for the training process.    All of the universities reporting to the federal ministry (248) have transferred their educational operations to an online format. Several online resources have also been launched: a situation center and a hot line,  a YouTube channel for online broadcasts of meetings and workshops, a Telegram channel @minobrnaukiofficial, and a website for universities (“Keep learning, Keep teaching”) with methodological support. An online platform established by the Agency of Strategic Initiatives, The University 2035, provides additional methodological support to universities.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210617183930/https://www.mos.ru/en/city/projects/covid-19/  http://web.archive.org/web/20210617191412/https://www.worldbank.org/en/country/russia/brief/covid-19-response-poor-vulnerable-russia  http://web.archive.org/web/20210617191538/https://www.worldbank.org/en/country/russia/brief/covid-19-response-macro-fiscal-russia  http://web.archive.org/web/20210617191754/https://www.themoscowtimes.com/2021/06/17/coronavirus-in-russia-the-latest-news-june-17-a69117  http://web.archive.org/web/20210617192006/https://ru.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Moscow has extended its coronavirus restrictions until June 29, Mayor Sobyanin announced. Outdoor theatres, playgrounds, food courts, children’s playrooms in malls, and zoos will remain closed through June 29. Restaurants and bars must close from 11 p.m. to 6 a.m. Theatres, movie theatres, museums and other cultural venues will only be able to serve 1,000 people at a time. Fan zones, dance floors and other venues for mass events will be closed.     https://archive.vn/GAnse

The authorities of Buryatia have decided to return to tough restrictions due to the increase in the incidence of COVID-19. A total lockdown (non-working day regime) is being introduced in the republic from June 27 to July 11     https://archive.vn/5KJwv

Moscow authorities reimposed work-from-home restrictions as the Russian capital posted a new daily record for Covid-19 deaths due to a surging outbreak of the Delta variant. In a decree published on his website, Mayor Sergei Sobyanin ordered that businesses cut their number of in-office workers by 30% from June 28. Vaccinated employees would be excluded, the decree said, adding that all workers aged over 65 as well as those with pre-existing conditions would have to work from home. From June 28, all Moscow cafes and restaurants will only serve customers who have been vaccinated; who have had Covid-19 in the past six months; or who present a negative Covid-19 test taken within the past 78 hours.      https://archive.vn/GAnse

As of June 25, Moscow authorities reinforce remote work restrictions. Business need to cut their number of in-office workers by 30 %. Vaccinated employees are excluded. Workers aged over 65 and workers with pre-conditions need to work from home.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210705155159/https://www.themoscowtimes.com/2021/07/05/coronavirus-in-russia-the-latest-news-july-5-a69117

‘In the Moscow region, indoor gatherings of more than 50 people and outdoors events of more than 500 are prohibited. In the city of Moscow, the mayor has implemented a system of QR codes for those seeking to dine in restaurants and cafes. Starting from June 28, 2021, all patrons at restaurants and bars will need to utilize an application connecting to a centralized government database in order to generate a QR code proving that they have either: been vaccinated, recovered from COVID-19 within the last six months, or had a negative PCR test result from an approved Moscow lab within the last three days. Otherwise, they will not be permitted to enter. Moscow authorities will only accept evidence of vaccination with one of the vaccines registered in the Russian Federation. The Moderna, Pfizer, and Johnson & Johnson vaccines are not currently registered in the Russian Federation.’    https://web.archive.org/web/20210705155813/https://ru.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

The Government of the Russian Federation banned the entry of foreign nationals, including American citizens, with a few exceptions.  The ban does not apply to: airplane crew members, permanent residents of the Russian Federation who hold a valid residence permit, or transit passengers. In addition, the Russian government allows entry of foreigners for medical treatment or in order to care for relatives in Russia.    The Russian government requires that all foreign travelers present a negative PCR COVID-19 test result upon arrival, dated no later than three days prior to arrival in Russia. The results can be in English and/or digital. Foreign travelers must also complete the attached form (PDF, 210Kb), print, and present to customs upon arrival in Russia  Are health screening procedures in place at airports and other ports of entry? Yes  Mandatory temperature screenings and other diagnostic and protective measures are being implemented at international airports and other major transit hubs. The Russian Federation no longer requires all travelers to quarantine for 14 days directly after arrival in Russia.  Local jurisdictions set their own rules regarding quarantine requirements for travelers arriving in the country.      http://web.archive.org/web/20210617183930/https://www.mos.ru/en/city/projects/covid-19/  http://web.archive.org/web/20210617191412/https://www.worldbank.org/en/country/russia/brief/covid-19-response-poor-vulnerable-russia  http://web.archive.org/web/20210617191538/https://www.worldbank.org/en/country/russia/brief/covid-19-response-macro-fiscal-russia  http://web.archive.org/web/20210617191754/https://www.themoscowtimes.com/2021/06/17/coronavirus-in-russia-the-latest-news-june-17-a69117  http://web.archive.org/web/20210617192006/https://ru.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Moscow increased unemployment benefits to support the unemployed. One was able to apply for this payment online without leaving one’s home. The employment service continued to employ people even during the most difficult months. 177 thousand people were provided with jobs in 2020.  The unemployed will shortly begin receiving monthly child support benefits worth of 3,000 rubles. This money will supplement the federal and regional unemployment benefits. Benefits for low-income families with children aged 3 to 7 were raised in Moscow to 7,613 rubles per month. This amount will continue to be paid after the coronavirus pandemic is over. Besides, the city supports low-income families with children, disabled people and other people in need. Many state services can be received online. Mos.ru comprises almost 400 electronic services.  (...) Entry into San Marino from an Italian red or orange zone is only permitted in cases of necessity, health or work. There are no restrictions on entering San Marino from a designated white or yellow zone. However, if your journey started outside of Italy, in the 14 days prior to your arrival in San Marino, you must show evidence of a negative molecular or antigenic swab test, taken within 48 hours of your arrival in San Marino. Children under the age of 10 do not need to show evidence of a test. Your test certificate must be emailed in advance to laboratorio.analisi@iss.sm.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210607135647/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/san-marino/coronavirus

Authorities are maintaining measures imposed to combat the spread of COVID-19. Officials are operating a traffic light system to indicate COVID-19-related international travel restrictions. Countries are classified as Green, Red, or Black depending on local infection rates, the presence of COVID-19 variants, and the reliability of epidemiological data. Arrivals from all locations are obliged to self-isolate for 14 days on arrival.   Travellers who have only spent time in Green countries in the previous 14 days can end their isolation period following an RT-PCR COVID-19 test at any point; travellers who have visited Red countries in the previous 14 days can end self-isolation following a negative RT-PCR test taken no less than eight days after arrival; travellers who have visited Black countries in the previous 14 days are not eligible to end their isolation period early. Additionally, travellers arriving from Green countries are exempt from the quarantine requirement if they can prove they have been vaccinated against COVID-19 or recovered from COVID-19 in the previous 180 days.  Nonessential travel is permitted from within the Schengen Area, Australia, China, Israel, Japan, New Zealand, Rwanda, Singapore, South Korea, and Thailand; travel from other countries is restricted to EU citizens and limited essential purposes only. All travellers arriving by air must register in advance using the Electronic Passenger Search Form; they must also fill out the Travel Registration Form immediately upon arrival. Exceptions to the entry restrictions are in place for transport workers and individuals in transit.     https://archive.vn/HU6zf   https://archive.vn/mOkFm   https://archive.vn/uT44T   https://archive.vn/P32m7    https://archive.vn/xoQva

Measures introduced by the coalition government include (i) wage compensation for affected businesses and self-employed, and subsidies to individuals without income (subsequently extended to June 2021 and augmented in size); (ii) enhanced unemployment benefits, and sickness and nursing benefits; (iii) deferral and waiver of employers' social security contributions for some months for affected companies and self-employed (deferral extended to June 2021); (iv) easing of the administrative burden on businesses and relaxing labour code requirements; (v) deferral of payroll and corporate tax payments for businesses whose revenues decline by more than 40 per cent; (vi) allowing companies to include loss carryback since 2014; (vii) rental subsidies; and (viii) higher medical spending.     https://archive.vn/N3iZk

Are PCR and/or antigen tests are generally available. Private testing is available at Agellab.sk, Synlab.sk , Alphamedical.sk, Lab.online, Rychlotest-covid.sk or Medirex.sk in various locations throughout the country. Rychlotest-covid.sk offers the cheapest PCR test in Bratislava for €36,90 with result coming in less than 26 hours after sample is taken, also with an English certificate. Reportedly, Medirex. sk offers same-day PCR results in English. If not ordered by the Regional Public Health Authority or a medical provider, the fee for testing is paid by the traveller. The standard cost for PCR tests is €50-€80. Results are usually provided via text message with a link to a document that can be downloaded for printing.  Fee-based testing will be available and may be required, at selected borders including some airports in the region.    Residents and visitors can also undergo free rapid antigen testing in each district upon request at facilities listed on the e-VUC website, many of which take walk-in patients.   https://archive.vn/xEobb

Following consultation with the Ministry of Health's advisory group, the Government determined that at this time the situation does not yet allow any significant further easing of measures. The following decisions were adopted:  With the ordinance temporarily prohibiting the offering and sale of goods and services to consumers, the Government further eases the following restrictions in the business sector:   1)	from Monday, 7 June 2021, restrictions on chimney sweeping services and construction works are easing,  2)	the convention industry is reopened in full; however, employees and consumers are required to comply with the recovered vaccinated tested requirements,  3)	the ban on consuming the collected foods and beverages at collection points is being lifted.  The Government has also eased the restrictions on the provision of accommodation services.   Another important change is access to swimming pools for all guests who meet the recovered vaccinated tested requirements;  shopping centres are required to provide 10 m2 per customer throughout the shopping centre.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210607200609/https://www.gov.si/en/news/2021-06-03-the-zvem-web-portal-as-main-access-point-to-acquire-a-digital-covid-certificate/

Gathering of people at organized public events and public gatherings is also now allowed (under the conditions set by the Public Gatherings Act).  Public gatherings are subject to the following restrictions:  the number of persons in enclosed spaces is limited to one participant per 10 square meters of enclosed space or more participants in the case of persons sharing the same household,   the number of persons in the open air is limited to one participant per 10 square meters or more participants in the case of persons sharing the same household,   the distance between participants must be at least 1.5 meters, except between persons sharing the same household,  protective masks are mandatory in all enclosed public spaces.  https://archive.fo/Xx7ZB#selection-1725.0-1783.45

The government of Slovenia made changes to Slovenia's entry requirements. As of Saturday, 5 June, a negative rapid antigen test result is again accepted for entry into Slovenia, provided that less than 48 hours have passed since the swab was taken. Both PCR and rapid tests are deemed sufficient if performed in an EU Member State, a Schengen Area country, Australia, Israel, Canada, New Zealand, Russia, Serbia, the UK or the US, at check points on flight connections of international air transport, and in Turkey. One further condition applies to rapid tests: only tests that are on the common list of COVID-19 rapid antigen tests recognised by the EU Member States are valid.  There are no changes for persons who have recovered from COVID-19 or have been vaccinated; such persons may enter Slovenia without being required to quarantine.  A person arriving from an area not on the red or dark red list may enter Slovenia without being ordered to quarantine at home if upon entry they provide proof of having resided in an area that is not on the red or dark red list for at least five consecutive days prior to entry. The change here is that if the period is shorter than five days, the person is only required to provide proof for the period from the time of departure from Slovenia to their return to Slovenia. If they are not able to provide relevant proof, they are considered to have come from an area on the red or dark red list.  Otherwise,  quarantine is required.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210607200609/https://www.gov.si/en/news/2021-06-03-the-zvem-web-portal-as-main-access-point-to-acquire-a-digital-covid-certificate/

Everyone entering Slovenia from a country on the Dark Red List or the Red List will be required to quarantine for 10 days. Quarantine can be ended after 5 days, with a negative PCR test. Quarantine can be avoided if travellers meet one of the specific exemptions that are listed by the Slovenian government (the list of exemptions can be found on the border crossing page of the Slovene website), or:    they are able to provide a negative PCR test result or a negative Rapid Antigen Test that is not more than 48 hours old and that has been administered in Australia, Canada, the EU, Israel, New Zealand, Russia, the Schengen Area, Seria, the UK or the US; or    they have proof of a COVID-19 vaccination as follows:    A second dose of Pfizer/BioNTech at least 7 days before arrival;  A second dose of Moderna vaccine at least 14 days before arrival;  A first dose of Oxford/AstraZeneca vaccine at least 21 days before arrival;  A second dose of the Sputnik V vaccine at least 21 days before arrival;  The Johnson & Johnson Janssen vaccine at least 21 days before arrival;  The Serum Institute of India/AstraZeneca at least 21 days before arrival;  A second dose of the Sinovac Biotech at least 14 days before arrival;  A second dose of the Sinopharm at least 14 days before arrival;  One dose of any of the above vaccines within eight months of recovering; or  they have recovered from COVID-19 and hold immunity. Proof of immunity can be demonstrated by a written medical statement from a health professional showing they had the first symptoms of COVID-19 within 6 months prior to arrival; or evidence of a positive test conducted at a recognised institution (see paragraph below) older than 21 days but less than 6 months.  https://archive.fo/pYWTA

There are screening procedures at the airport. Quarantine is only needed in lack of vaccination or PCR testing prior to entry or in case of showing symptoms.   http://web.archive.org/web/20210607203654/https://si.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

In order to further reduce the risk, the government has extended the measures of reimbursement of wage compensation for workers on furlough until the end of June. It is a measure that both the government and employers assess as the most successful in preserving jobs. More than EUR 538 million has been earmarked for it so far - to 31,631 employers for 214,225 employees.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210607200851/https://www.gov.si/en/news/2021-05-28-vaccination-contributes-to-improving-the-situation-in-care-homes/

A, B, C. Pfizer/Biotech vaccine, AstraZeneca, Moderna and Janssen.    Increased vaccine supply has accelerated the vaccination of the population. Coded as 1 to reflect that even though they are open, there are still restrictions in place for almost all workplaces which limit the number of visitors/customers.    From 1 June, all workplaces can open again in some capacity. Until then, amusement parks of a permanent nature and amusement facilities (rides) in zoos and theme parks had been covered by the ban on public gatherings, requiring them to remain closed, but these now fall under the regulations that require them to calculate the maximum number of visitors so that each visitor has at least 20m².    Shops, gyms, indoor sports facilities, and swimming facilities must calculate the number of visitors so that each person gets at least 10m². They must have clear signage that clarifies for visitors how many people may visit the premises at the same time.    Restaurants, cafés and bars can, from 1 June, be open until 22.30 and alcohol can be served until 22.00. Takeaway of food and of non-alcoholic drinks is allowed later than that.  The size of a dining party allowed to sit at one table is limited to four people. If a party is larger, they must be divided between several tables with at least one metre between them.  Venues serving food and drink have to implement hygiene measures incl the prevention of crowding.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210604185413/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/verksamheter/tillsynsvagledning-for-verksamheter/    http://web.archive.org/web/20210604185422/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/restriktioner-och-forbud

Coded as 1 to reflect that even though they are open, there are still restrictions in place for almost all workplaces which limit the number of visitors/customers.    All workplaces can open again in some capacity. Until then, amusement parks of a permanent nature and amusement facilities (rides) in zoos and theme parks had been covered by the ban on public gatherings, requiring them to remain closed, but these now fall under the regulations that require them to calculate the maximum number of visitors so that each visitor has at least 20 sqm of space.    Shops, gyms, indoor sports facilities, and swimming facilities must calculate the number of visitors so that each person gets at least 10m². They must have clear signage that clarifies for visitors how many people may visit the premises at the same time.    Restaurants, cafés and bars can be open until 22.30 and alcohol can be served until 22.00. Takeaway of food and of non-alcoholic drinks is allowed later than that.  The size of a dining party allowed to sit at one table is limited to four people. If a party is larger, they must be divided between several tables with at least one metre between them.  Venues serving food and drink have to implement hygiene measures incl the prevention of crowding.     Businesses with premises that are so large that they can let in 500 or more customers or visitors should perform a special risk assessment to determine whether there is a risk of crowding in the business premises, parts of the premises or close to the premises. The businesses should take special infection control measures to reduce the risk of crowding in such places.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210628132217/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/verksamheter/tillsynsvagledning-for-verksamheter/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210622212835/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/current-rules-and-recommendations

Workplaces are open but there are still restrictions in place which limit the number of visitors/customers, opening hours, etc. From 1 July, these rules have been further loosened, but some restrictions remain in place.     Shops, gyms, indoor sports facilities, and swimming facilities must calculate the number of visitors so that each person gets at least 10m². They must have clear signage that clarifies for visitors how many people may visit the premises at the same time.    Restaurants, cafés and bars can be open until 22.30 and alcohol can be served until 22.00. Takeaway of food and of non-alcoholic drinks is allowed later than that.  The size of a dining party allowed to sit at one table is limited to 8 people. If a party is larger, they must be divided between several tables with at least one metre between them.  Venues serving food and drink have to implement hygiene measures incl the prevention of crowding.     Businesses with premises that are so large that they can let in 500 or more customers or visitors should perform a special risk assessment to determine whether there is a risk of crowding in the business premises, parts of the premises or close to the premises. The businesses should take special infection control measures to reduce the risk of crowding in such places.     Fairs are now regulated in the same way as markets. This means e.g. that the trade fair organizer must inform its visitors and exhibitors about how the spread of infection can be avoided and design corridors between the points of sale or the stands so that congestion is avoided. The provision contains general advice that the organizer should assign the exhibitors a place with a distance of at least 2 meters sideways and backwards and for longer distances in the corridors. Those who organize a trade fair that covers special risks from the point of view of infection control should make a special risk assessment and take special measures to reduce the risk of the spread of infection, for example at a lecture, when people are in a place for a long time.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210703074016/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/verksamheter/tillsynsvagledning-for-verksamheter/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210703074022/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/current-rules-and-recommendations

Coded as 1 to reflect that some public events can take place, but that significant restrictions remain in place.      From 1 June, the rules on maximum numbers of participants in general gatherings and public events have changed:   - For indoor events with designated seating, the limit was raised to 50 participants. For indoor events without designated seating, the limit remains at 8 participants.   - For outdoor events with designated seating, the number of participants was increased to 500 people. For outdoor events without designated seating, the limit was raised to 100 people.  - At outdoor sports and competition events, such as races, the number of participants was increased to 150 people.  - The Public Health Agency has the opportunity to decide on lowered participation ceilings regionally.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210604185436/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/news/2021/may/adapted-restrictions-to-be-introduced-1-june     http://web.archive.org/web/20210604185429/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/skydda-dig-och-andra/max-antal-deltagare-i-sammankomster-och-i-olika-lokaler/

Coded as 1 to reflect that more public events can take place, but that significant restrictions remain in place.      Size of public gatherings and public events:   - Indoor event without seating: 8 participants.   - Indoor events with seating: 50 participants (groups must be able to keep a distance of at least 1 m sideways. Each group may not exceed 4 people).   - Outdoor event without seating: 100 participants.   - Outdoor event with seating: 500 participants.   - Sports event: 150 participants.   - Funerals may have 20 participants regardless of the size of the room or 50 participants if the party can keep a distance of at least 1 meter sideways and forwards and backwards from other parties. Each party may not exceed 4 people.   - Private events in rented premises: 8 people.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210618172113/https://www.krisinformation.se/detta-kan-handa/handelser-och-storningar/20192/myndigheterna-om-det-nya-coronaviruset/coronapandemin-detta-galler-just-nu     http://web.archive.org/web/20210618172305/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/skydda-dig-och-andra/max-antal-deltagare-i-sammankomster-och-i-olika-lokaler/     On 14 June, the Public Health Agency made a proposal to the government that would make it possible to increase the participation ceilings even more. The rules on sectioning could be implemented when level 2 enters, tentatively around 1 July. Instead of a maximum ceiling of 3,000 seated outdoors, a public gathering or public event could, for example, have 9,000 seated audiences if they were divided into three separate sections. The prerequisite is that it is done in combination with other infection control measures.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210618172220/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/juni/publik-i-sektioner-kan-gora-storre-evenemang-mojliga-enligt-forslag/

Coded as 1 to reflect that more public events can take place, but that significant restrictions remain in place.     - Indoor event without seating: 8 participants.   - Indoor events with seating: 50 participants (groups must be able to keep a distance of at least 1 m on each side. Groups may not exceed 4 people).   - Outdoor event without seating: 100 participants.   - Outdoor event with seating: 500 participants.   - Sports event: 150 participants.   - Funerals may have 20 mourners regardless of the size of the room or 50 mourners if the party can keep a distance of at least 1 meter on each side and forwards and backwards from other parties. Each party may not exceed 4 people.   - Private events in rented premises: 8 people.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210628132231/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/current-rules-and-recommendations     http://web.archive.org/web/20210628132226/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/skydda-dig-och-andra/max-antal-deltagare-i-sammankomster-och-i-olika-lokaler/     On 14 June, the Public Health Agency made a proposal to the government that would make it possible to increase the participation ceilings even more. The rules on sectioning could be implemented when level 2 enters, tentatively around 1 July. Instead of a maximum ceiling of 3,000 seated outdoors, a public gathering or public event could, for example, have 9,000 seated audiences if they were divided into three separate sections. The prerequisite is that it is done in combination with other infection control measures.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210628132230/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/juni/publik-i-sektioner-kan-gora-storre-evenemang-mojliga-enligt-forslag/

Most public events can take place, but some restrictions remain in place. From 1 July, the thresholds of maximum participants have been further lowered.     - Indoor event without seating: 50 participants.   - Indoor events with seating: 300 participants (groups must be able to keep a distance of at least 1 m on each side. Groups may not exceed 4 people).   - Outdoor event without seating: 600 participants.   - Outdoor event with seating: 3000 participants.   - Sports event: 900 participants.   - Funerals may have 20 mourners regardless of the size of the room or 50 mourners if the party can keep a distance of at least 1 meter on each side and forwards and backwards from other parties. Each party may not exceed 4 people.   - Private events in rented premises: 50 people.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210703074022/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/current-rules-and-recommendations

There is a travel ban on non-essential travel to Sweden from countries outside the EU. This ban is valid until August 31. There is a list of countries exempt from the ban, because the risk of contagion with Covid-19 is deemed to be low: Australia, New Zealand, Rwanda, Singapore, South Korea, Thailand, Israel. The criteria for being granted an entry to Sweden is based on people residing in one of those countries, not citizenship. Travellers to Sweden should thus bring proof of living in one of these countries.       The entry ban does not apply to citizens and their families from EU/EEA countries and Switzerland. The ban also does not apply if you are a permanent resident or hold a residence permit in Sweden or another EU country, or if you have a national visa in Sweden.     Foreign nationals need to present a negative Covid-19 test result in order to travel into Sweden. There can be no more than 48 hours between the time of the Covid test and crossing the border. The following types of test are approved: Antigen tests, TMA-test, PCR tests and LAMP tests. From 31 May, the requirement for travellers from Denmark, Finland, Norway and Iceland to show a negative covid test was removed.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210603072346/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/travel-restrictions

There is a travel ban on non-essential travel to Sweden from countries outside the EU. This ban is valid until August 31. There is a list of countries exempt from the ban, because the risk of contagion with Covid-19 is deemed to be low. Currently exempt countries: Australia, New Zealand, Rwanda, Singapore, South Korea, Thailand, Israel, Japan. From 30 June 2021, those living in one of the following countries will be allowed to enter Sweden: Albania, Hong Kong, Lebanon, Macao, North Macedonia, Serbia, Taiwan, and the USA. The criteria for being granted an entry to Sweden is based on people residing in one of those countries, not citizenship. Travellers to Sweden should thus bring proof of living in one of these countries.       The entry ban does not apply to citizens and their families from EU/EEA countries and Switzerland. The ban also does not apply if you are a permanent resident or hold a residence permit in Sweden or another EU country, or if you have a national visa in Sweden.     Foreign nationals, except those travelling from the Nordic countries (Finland, Norway, Denmark, and Iceland), need to present a negative Covid-19 test result in order to travel into Sweden. There can be no more than 48 hours between the time of the Covid test and crossing the border. The following types of test are approved: Antigen tests, TMA-test, PCR tests and LAMP tests. Exceptions are made for foreign nationals who are registered residents in Sweden or who live in Sweden with a valid residence permit, right of residence or residence status. For these, the same rules apply as for Swedish citizens.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210618172737/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/travel-restrictions

No policy change, extension of policies:    Short-time working means that an employee reduces working hours and wages instead of being laid off. This means that employers can reduce employees' working hours and receive financial support from the Government to compensate for a significant part of the costs for retaining the employee. ... You can register an application to claim financial support from March 29th. The support can be applied for retroactively from December 1st, 2020 and can be received until June 30th 2021. … The government extends support for short-time working until June 2021. ... The support for short-time work allowance has been extended and the working hours can be reduced up to 80% for the months: May, June and July. ... The government has decided to temporarily suspend the deduction from sick pay for the qualifying period from 11 March 2020 to 30 June 2021.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210614145011/https://www.verksamt.se/web/international/running/gathered-information-to-entrepreneurs-due-to-the-corona-virus/for-employers

The government’s Public Health Agency’s extensive public information campaign continues via the government’s websites, but the weekly press conferences that have been hosted since March 2020 to announce the latest updates on covid developments and rules are put on hold from 1 July-12 August.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210703080709/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/juni/myndighetsgemensamma-presstraffar-pausas-under-sommaren/

Testing is recommended to anyone over 6 years old with symptoms + recommended to people who have travelled from abroad. If you have previously had COVID-19 in the past half-year and this was confirmed through a PCR test, an antigen test or an antibody test, you do not need to be retested for COVID-19, unless a doctor determines that you need to do so. However, you should stay at home as long as you have symptoms.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210604185523/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/the-public-health-agency-of-sweden/communicable-disease-control/covid-19/covid-19-testing/    http://web.archive.org/web/20210604185507/https://www.krisinformation.se/detta-kan-handa/handelser-och-storningar/20192/myndigheterna-om-det-nya-coronaviruset/reseinformation-med-anledning-av-det-nya-coronaviruset

**Note: Sweden has never had testing available to asymptomatic people, so I don’t think any recoding of H2 is required.**    Testing is recommended to anyone over 6 years old with symptoms + recommended to people who have travelled from abroad. If you have previously had COVID-19 in the past half-year and this was confirmed through a PCR test, an antigen test or an antibody test, you do not need to be retested for COVID-19, unless a doctor determines that you need to do so. However, you should stay at home as long as you have symptoms.     All types of corona tests, including self tests, are only available to those showing symptoms: http://web.archive.org/web/20210614144513/https://www.1177.se/Skane/sjukdomar--besvar/lungor-och-luftvagar/inflammation-och-infektion-ilungor-och-luftror/om-covid-19--coronavirus/lamna-prov-och-fa-provsvar-om-covid-19/bestall-test-for-covid--19/     http://web.archive.org/web/20210614144548/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/the-public-health-agency-of-sweden/communicable-disease-control/covid-19/covid-19-testing/     http://web.archive.org/web/20210614144547/https://www.krisinformation.se/detta-kan-handa/handelser-och-storningar/20192/myndigheterna-om-det-nya-coronaviruset/reseinformation-med-anledning-av-det-nya-coronaviruset

Testing is recommended to anyone over 6 years old with symptoms + recommended to people who have travelled from abroad. If you have previously had COVID-19 in the past half-year and this was confirmed through a PCR test, an antigen test or an antibody test, you do not need to be retested for COVID-19, unless a doctor determines that you need to do so. However, you should stay at home as long as you have symptoms.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210614144548/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/the-public-health-agency-of-sweden/communicable-disease-control/covid-19/covid-19-testing/     http://web.archive.org/web/20210618175308/https://www.krisinformation.se/detta-kan-handa/handelser-och-storningar/20192/myndigheterna-om-det-nya-coronaviruset/reseinformation-med-anledning-av-det-nya-coronaviruset     All types of corona tests, including self tests, are only available to those showing symptoms: http://web.archive.org/web/20210618172715/https://www.1177.se/Skane/sjukdomar--besvar/lungor-och-luftvagar/inflammation-och-infektion-ilungor-och-luftror/om-covid-19--coronavirus/lamna-prov-och-fa-provsvar-om-covid-19/bestall-test-for-covid--19/

Testing is recommended to anyone over 6 years old with symptoms + recommended to people who have travelled from abroad. If you have previously had COVID-19 in the past half-year and this was confirmed through a PCR test, an antigen test or an antibody test, you do not need to be retested for COVID-19, unless a doctor determines that you need to do so. However, you should stay at home as long as you have symptoms.     PCR and antigen tests are only available to those showing symptoms. You have to order them or make an appointment to get tested online or at a health centre: http://web.archive.org/web/20210628133250/https://www.1177.se/Skane/sjukdomar--besvar/lungor-och-luftvagar/inflammation-och-infektion-ilungor-och-luftror/om-covid-19--coronavirus/lamna-prov-och-fa-provsvar-om-covid-19/bestall-test-for-covid--19 (link shows information for Skåne region, same or similar in other regions)     http://web.archive.org/web/20210620071039/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/the-public-health-agency-of-sweden/communicable-disease-control/covid-19/covid-19-testing/     http://web.archive.org/web/20210628132456/https://www.krisinformation.se/detta-kan-handa/handelser-och-storningar/20192/myndigheterna-om-det-nya-coronaviruset/reseinformation-med-anledning-av-det-nya-coronaviruset

No change:   The regions of Blekinge, Örebro, Gävleborg, Halland, Norrbotten, Stockholm, Södermanland, Uppsala, Västerbotten, Västmanland, and Västra Götaland have introduced more extensive mask recommendations: the use of masks on public transport at all times, not only during rush hours, and when there is prolonged (15+ min) close contact with other people indoors.     This is coded as 2T to reflect the broader scope of application and stronger language (""must always be worn"") of this recommendation compared to the national-level recommendation for rush hour mask use in public transport.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210604185525/https://www.krisinformation.se/detta-kan-handa/handelser-och-storningar/20192/myndigheterna-om-det-nya-coronaviruset/regional-information-om-coronaviruset

A number of regions have introduced more extensive mask recommendations: the use of masks on public transport at all times, not only during rush hours, and when there is prolonged (15+ min) close contact with other people indoors.     This is coded as 2T to reflect the broader scope of application and stronger language (""must always be worn"") of this recommendation compared to the national-level recommendation for rush hour mask use in public transport.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210614144946/https://www.krisinformation.se/detta-kan-handa/handelser-och-storningar/20192/myndigheterna-om-det-nya-coronaviruset/regional-information-om-coronaviruset

Until 13 June, some regions had regional recommendations to use masks in public transport and other public places in which keeping a distance is not possible. The last region to have a stricter local mask recommendation seems to have been Stockholm, where this recommendation is no longer in place since 14 June: https://web.archive.org/web/20210601133307/https://www.sll.se/verksamhet/halsa-och-vard/om-det-nya-coronaviruset/nya-regionala-rekommendationer-for-stockholms-lan/    Värmland still has regional recommendations (11-27 June), but these do not mention mask use: https://web.archive.org/web/20210613090753/https://www.regionvarmland.se/om-regionen/pressrum/Pressmeddelanden/2021/06/tillfalliga-lokala-rekommendationer-infors-i-varmland/     The national recommendation to wear a mask on public transport during rush hours on weekdays remains in place.

From July 1, public transportation recommendations on masks dropped. https://web.archive.org/web/20210705133108/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/skydda-dig-och-andra/anpassning-av-atgarder-mot-spridning-av-covid-19/

All regions now appear to be in Phase 4 (all adults, offered in a staggered way, opening up to five-year age groups at a time): everyone over 50 (and in many regions younger than that, too) is now eligible to get vaccinated.     Details per region:   http://web.archive.org/web/20210604185515/https://www.thelocal.se/20210414/where-is-the-vaccination-programme-up-to-in-swedens-21-regions/  http://web.archive.org/web/20210604185525/https://www.krisinformation.se/detta-kan-handa/handelser-och-storningar/20192/myndigheterna-om-det-nya-coronaviruset/regional-information-om-coronaviruset    Type of vaccine: Pfizer, Moderna, AstraZeneca    - Details on delivery of the 3 vaccines in use: http://web.archive.org/web/20210604185803/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/statistik-och-analyser/leveranser-av-vaccin/  - The use of the Janssen vaccin is suspended for all age groups. ""The vaccine is not recommended for people under 65, and those over 65 will have received other vaccines before Janssen's vaccine can be delivered."" http://web.archive.org/web/20210507150759/https://www.krisinformation.se/nyheter/20212/april2/fortsatt-paus-for-janssens-vaccin   - The recommendation to only use AstraZeneca for people over 65 remains: http://web.archive.org/web/20210507150801/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/april/rekommendation-om-aldersgrans-pa-65-ar-for-astrazenecas-vaccin-kvarstar/   But anyone under the age of 65 who has already received a first dose of Astra Zeneca's vaccine can also receive their second dose of the same vaccine if they specifically request it. The recommendation to offer the mRNA vaccine as a second dose still applies. http://web.archive.org/web/20210507150836/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/april/tillatet-att-valja-astra-zeneca-for-de-yngre-som-tidigare-fatt-en-forsta-dos/      Vaccinations are still taking place:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210603070741/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/statistik-och-analyser/statistik-over-registrerade-vaccinationer-covid-19/

All regions are in vaccination phase 4, in which the vaccine is offered to all adults in a staggered way, opening up to five-year age groups at a time. Currently, everyone over 50 is now eligible to get vaccinated. Kronoberg is currently the least advanced region, offering over-50s the vaccine, most region offer people over 40 and several have advanced even further. ""The vaccine is not recommended for people under 65, and those over 65 will have received other vaccines before Janssen's vaccine can be delivered."" http://web.archive.org/web/20210507150759/https://www.krisinformation.se/nyheter/20212/april2/fortsatt-paus-for-janssens-vaccin  - The recommendation to only use AstraZeneca for people over 65 remains: http://web.archive.org/web/20210507150801/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/april/rekommendation-om-aldersgrans-pa-65-ar-for-astrazenecas-vaccin-kvarstar/  But anyone under the age of 65 who has already received a first dose of Astra Zeneca's vaccine can also receive their second dose of the same vaccine if they specifically request it. The recommendation to offer the mRNA vaccine as a second dose still applies. http://web.archive.org/web/20210507150836/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/april/tillatet-att-valja-astra-zeneca-for-de-yngre-som-tidigare-fatt-en-forsta-dos/     Vaccinations are still taking place:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210614144611/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/statistik-och-analyser/statistik-over-registrerade-vaccinationer-covid-19/

No change:  The general recommendations for visitors of elderly homes include:   - Stay at home if you feel ill. Cancel the visit even in case of mild symptoms.   - Wash your hands before, during and after the visit.   - Even if the person you are visiting has been vaccinated, you need to keep your distance from other people during the visit, both indoors and outdoors.   - There are local procedures for visits. Ask the staff about the procedures that apply at the care home you are visiting.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210604185542/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/publicerat-material/publikationsarkiv/p/prevent-the-spread-of-covid-19-when-visiting-care-homes-for-older-people/    A person who has been vaccinated with a first dose and allowed three weeks to pass can meet people from a few different households and even indoors. ... The changes mean, among other things, that people who have been vaccinated can spend time with children and grandchildren indoors without keeping their distance, provided that they have no symptoms.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210604185810/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/april/anpassade-rekommendationer-efter-vaccination/

Ask the staff about the procedures that apply at the care home you are visiting.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210614144613/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/publicerat-material/publikationsarkiv/p/prevent-the-spread-of-covid-19-when-visiting-care-homes-for-older-people/    A person who has been vaccinated with a first dose and allowed three weeks to pass can meet people from a few different households and even indoors. ... Ask the staff about the procedures that apply at the care home you are visiting.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210618175718/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/publicerat-material/publikationsarkiv/p/prevent-the-spread-of-covid-19-when-visiting-care-homes-for-older-people/    A person who has been vaccinated with a first dose and allowed three weeks to pass can meet people from a few different households and even indoors. ... The changes mean, among other things, that people who have been vaccinated can spend time with children and grandchildren indoors without keeping their distance, provided that they have no symptoms.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210628133932/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2021/april/anpassade-rekommendationer-efter-vaccination/

No evidence of continued income support for households. The below source, although updated to show facts from 7th May 2021, tracks what has happened historically. The below source shows there has been income support given to workers in 2020, but there is a lack of evidence that this is still being continued.   ____________________________________  Quote:"" Key Policy Responses as of May 7, 2021  The Government is providing VAT exemptions on essential imports, lump-sum assistance equivalent to minimum wage to vulnerable households and other socially disadvantaged groups. Health workers are to receive supplemental pay, while tariff increases on electricity, water, and communal services have been postponed until end of 2020. Government is providing free medical care to citizens placed under medical care and COVID-19 patients, as well as sick leave and compensation benefits. Government is providing grain, seed and fuel to farms to boost food security, and time-bound tax holidays and relief to targeted industries and small businesses until September 1, 2020. Anti-COVID measures also include financial support to SMEs and subsidizing food for population. ""  Archive Link  http://web.archive.org/web/20210530195843/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

AstraZeneca  Vaccination of three groups: 'medical workers... people over 60 and people with chronic diseases'. Some 'high profile public health figures' also received the vaccine. (See Source 1, linked)     Although there is talk of Tajikistan receiving doses of the Sputnik V and CoronaVac vaccines from Russia and China respectively (See Source 1, linked), at present there is evidence only that the AstraZeneca vaccine is being administered (See Source 2).    It is said to be free of charge but there are reports that people are being charged and also being told that vaccination is compulsory (See Source 3). Domestic rail transport resumed normal operations on June 1; however, authorities have extended an existing suspension on intercity bus transportation through at least June 15. Domestic flights are operating on a significantly reduced schedule. Security forces continue to man checkpoints on roads entering Ashgabat. Checkpoints have also been reported on highways in Balkan, Mary, Lebap, and Dashoguz provinces, where health screenings have been carried out. Special permits are required for travel within or between provinces.  https://archive.vn/nlUwq  http://web.archive.org/web/20210614205140/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/turkmenistan/coronavirus  http://web.archive.org/web/20210614225533/https://tm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

International commercial flights remain suspended. All land borders with Afghanistan, Iran, Kazakhstan, and Uzbekistan are closed until further notice. Only Turkmen nationals, permanent residents, diplomats, and workers in critical industries and key infrastructure are permitted to enter the country. All arrivals must undergo a 14-day quarantine in a state-run facility.   https://archive.vn/nlUwq  http://web.archive.org/web/20210614225533/https://tm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  http://web.archive.org/web/20210614205140/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/turkmenistan/coronavirus

Archive Link  http://web.archive.org/web/20210704222023/https://tm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  _________________________________________________________________  Quote: ""Turkmenistan was the first country in the CCA to register for the Russian vaccines Sputnik V and EpiVacCorona. Any Turkmen citizen who has the age of 18 and above can register for the vaccine. Polyclinics in Ashgabat and in the regions stated that citizens started signing up for the vaccine.""    ""As of 4 April 2021, a total of 41,993 vaccine doses have been disbursed in Turkmenistan.    Turkmenistan has vaccinated all of their medical staff, public officials, teachers in schools and higher education, and elderly people. They are now in the process of vaccinating the population aged 60 and above.""
